Ringneck parrots are known for their talking abilities
column2: but that doesn’t always guarantee that they will.  Ringneck parrots need to be interacted with daily and need a lot of mental stimulation so they don’t get bored.  They can get loud and do go through what’s called a bluffing stage.  If you’ve never owned a bird
column3: I would not recommend this type of parrot as your first.  Always do your research before bringing home a parrot.  Ringneck parrots can live anywhere between 25 years of age and above. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/talking-parrot-says-choo-choo-220520251.html#p1qMKhoy8

column1: 2020-12-29 16:23:46#sport#'Love always wins
column2: ' Duke and Duchess of Sussex tell listeners in their first podcast#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/love-always-wins-duke-duchess-162346766.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/zziWbj1SnmKaS8RTX2DaMA--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMjUx/https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/4xxoaVFu22XtGQAAGwnyRg--~B/aD0xNTY0O3c9MjUwMDthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/74977d5cfc27ef6f34912b755e367cbd#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"It has been almost a year to the day since the Duke and Duchess of Sussex announced that they would be stepping back as senior royals
column3: prompting dismay from Buckingham Palace and bitter recriminations from both sides.  Yet few could deny that the couple have had quite a year
column4: snapping up a sprawling Californian mansion and signing a string of lucrative business deals.  Perhaps mindful of their triumph in the face of perceived adversity
column5: the couple used their first Spotify podcast on Tuesday to send a poignant message to their supporters
column6: telling them: ""Trust us when we say love always wins. "" They reinforced the message with a personal song choice
column7: ""Amen
column8: This Little Light of Mine""
column9: by Karen Gibson and the Kingdom Choir
column10: which was played at their wedding
column11: as they wished listeners a Happy New Year.  ""Not a toast per se
column12: but a song
column13: which is about shining a light
column14: the Duke said.  ""The message of this song is one we hold so dearly.  It's about using the power we each have within us to make this world a better place. "" The Duchess quoted Martin Luther King as she said: ""It was the music that we wanted playing when we started our lives together.  Because as we all know
column15: 'darkness cannot drive out darkness
column16: only light can do that'. """#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/love-always-wins-duke-duchess-162346766.html#4A2VEmBZy

column1: 2020-12-28 15:00:06#sport#Hungry pelicans at Galapagos fish market swarm generous fishermen#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/hungry-pelicans-galapagos-fish-market-150006242.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/28/5fe9f42e5068c33bdc2cc342/5fe9f42e5068c33bdc2cc343_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#The Galapagos Islands are home to some of the most diverse and fascinating life on the planet.  These islands are very new in geological terms
column2: having emerged from the ocean due to volcanic eruptions 400 million years ago.  Barren and lifeless
column3: they were simply chunks of cooled lava until the surface changed over many years to support the first plants.  They were followed long after by sea birds and then animals that found their way there on rafts of floating vegetation.  Very slowly
column4: the islands became home to many species of plants and animals
column5: cut off from the rest of the world by the great distance from other land masses.  Life here on the islands has evolved on its own line
column6: with animals adapting to long periods of drought and hardship.  They have developed unique traits and physical characteristics that were important for the survival of the species.  The people of the Galapagos understand and respect the delicate balance of nature in this world.  They exist in harmony with the animals and interfere as little as possible.  They encourage others to respect this as well
column7: and tourists are gently reminded to let nature take care of its own.  But the pelicans are one of the exceptions.  Large
column8: strong birds with few predators
column9: they have little fear of the humans who bring in their morning catch of fish and lobster.  They pelicans have learned that there might be scraps and entrails to be had when the boats come in to the harbour.  This fish market on Santa Cruz is a popular destination for tourists and also for the locals.  The pelicans are not the only creatures looking for a free meal.  Marine iguanas
column10: giant frigates
column11: herons
column12: and also sea lions patrol the sidewalk and areas around the counter as the fishermen cut the fish and get it ready for sale.  Locals come for the opportunity of a fresh purchase
column13: and also for the entertainment as the animals gather in great numbers.  Throwing the entrails in the garbage and taking them to the landfill will result in scavengers getting their meals there.  It makes just as much sense to toss the waste in the direction of the eager and hungry mob of animals at the counter.  The pelicans scramble to move out of the way as people walk through
column14: but they quickly line up again
column15: salivating and keeping a sharp eye on the fish.  As the pelicans are tossed a large chunk by the generous fisherman
column16: they squawk in what sounds much like comical human laughter.  While in the Galapagos Islands
column17: a trip to the fish market is an absolute must
column18: especially with a camera. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/hungry-pelicans-galapagos-fish-market-150006242.html#giAZDgOb8

column1: 2020-12-28 17:00:00#sport#15 Cookbooks & Recipes To Slay New Year’s Resolutions With Flavor#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/11-cookbook-recipes-slay-apos-225357497.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/k4M1P57hILoEYSBwIeh9kw--~B/aD05MDA7dz0xMjAwO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/https://media.zenfs.com/en/refinery29_778/1072df3cc089c0a5e3c6994d90b54f94#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"New year
column2: new food resolution.  Whether your start to 2021 is all about eating more greens
column3: honing a set of lackluster cooking chops
column4: or just saving some extra dough by skipping weeknight takeout
column5: having the right support is key.  While the internet is an ever-flowing source of recipe inspiration
column6: the endless searchable options out there can feel overwhelming — especially when specific and resolve-testing resolutions come into play.  So
column7: instead of blindly blog-searching
column8: we're turning to the classic masters of recipe organization: cookbooks. When your quarantine cooking skills begin to weaken and wane
column9: there's a cookbook out there with a game plan.  When you feel like ""healthy"" snacks can't possibly branch past almonds and apples
column10: there's a creative recipe collection waiting to show you the light.  Ahead we've rounded up 15 curated-cooking guidebooks (along with a bonus recipe preview from most) to help you slay any new year
column11: new food resolution — from fast and easy sheet pan suppers to surprisingly vegan comfort dishes
column12: one-pot feasts
column13: inventive breakfast bites
column14: and much more. At Refinery29
column15: we’re here to help you navigate this overwhelming world of stuff.  All of our market picks are independently selected and curated by the editorial team.  If you buy something we link to on our site
column16: Refinery29 may earn commission. The Well Plated CookbookBest For: Practical Meals With A TwistPopular food blogger
column17: Erin Clarke
column18: just recently made her debut into the publishing world with her approachable yet delectable recipe guide
column19: The Well Plated Cookbook.  Inside all 320 pages you'll find main course showstoppers
column20: easy handheld treats
column21: and classic deserts made healthy.  What better way to start the new year than with a plate full of fundamental nutrients and satisfied tastebuds?Erin Clarke The Well Plated Cookbook
column23: available at AmazonPower Plates Best For: Well Balanced Meals That Just Happen To Be VeganThere is an ongoing debate about whether or not you can go vegan without sacrificing the energy you had whilst eating meat and dairy products.  Well
column24: this cookbook has arrived to put an end to the conversation via delicious one-dish power plates.  Inside you'll find recipes chock full of healthy fats
column27: it's a one-way ticket to a well-balanced and rejuvinating vegan diet.  Gena Hamshaw Power Plates: 100 Nutritionally Balanced Vegan Meals
column29: available at AmazonThe Kefir CookbookBest For: Adding Superfood Flavor To Your Favorite DishesKefir is a fermented and cultured dairy milk that's widely recognized around the world as not only a superfood but also the
column30: ""champagne of dairy. "" Whether you use its smooth-creamy texture and tangy-tart flavor to elevate an ordinary frittata
column33: the kefir recipe options are endless — and Julie Smolyansky's creative cookbook proves it. Julie Smolyansky The Kefir Cookbook
column35: available at AmazonPhoto: Courtesy of The Kefir Cookbook. Pan-Seared Salmon Burgers With TzatzikiServes 4Ingredients1 lb.  ground wild salmon 2 large brown eggs 1⁄4 cup minced shallots 1 tsp chopped fresh dill Juice of 1⁄2 lemon Maldon sea salt 2 tbsp extra virgin olive oil 4 brioche buns Tzatziki Lemon wedges
column42: and a pinch of sea salt.  Form the salmon mixture into 4 equal patties. 2.  In a cast-iron skillet
column43: heat the olive oil over medium heat.  Once the oil is slightly shimmering
column44: place the patties in the skillet and cook on one side until browned
column45: 3 to 4 minutes.  Flip the patties and finish cooking on the other side
column46: then remove the skillet from the heat. 3.  Divide the salmon burgers among four buns
column47: topping each with tzatziki.  Season very lightly with sea salt and a squeeze of lemon juice. Excerpted from The Kefir Cookbook: An Ancient Healing Superfood for Modern Life
column48: Recipes from My Family Table and Around the World.  Copyright © 2018 by Julie Smolyansky.  Reprinted with permission by HarperOne
column49: a division of Harper Collins Publishers. Julie Smolyansky The Kefir Cookbook
column51: available at AmazonPhoto: Courtesy of The Kefir Cookbook. Gentle Morning KitchariServes 4-6Ingredients1 tbsp coconut oil2 tsp mustard seeds1 tsp cumin seeds1 white or yellow onion
column53: peeled and diced1 tbsp finely grated or minced fresh ginger
column54: or 1 tsp ground ginger3/4 cyo white basmati or jasmine rice
column58: or red lentils1 tsp ground tumeric1/4 tsp ground cloves1 tsp salt1/4 tsp freshly ground black pepper4 cups low-sodium vegetable broth2 cups waterInstructions1.  Heat oil in a large pot over medium heat.  When the oil is shimmering
column59: add the mustard and cumin seeds and cook

column1: 2020-12-28 15:50:08#sport#Pack of Arctic wolves settle for a nap in the afternoon#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/pack-arctic-wolves-settle-nap-155008859.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/28/5fea0063e75f6906e84524db/5fea0066f7a4f600012e45c6_854x480_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Arctic wolves are beautiful creatures with long
column2: white fur to help them blend in with their snowy surroundings.  They are large and powerful animals with the males reaching a weight of up to 46kg (102lbs).  Most Arctic wolves are found in northern Canada.  Artic wolves have relatively little fear of people
column3: thought to be due to their infrequent exposure to humans.  Although attacks on humans are rare
column4: a few documented cases exist.  The Arctic wolf's primary food source is the muskoxen and Arctic hares
column5: although they also feed on caribou and lemmings.  Capable hunters
column6: the Arctic wolf has been found on two occasions to have preyed upon polar bear cubs.  Beautiful animals
column7: the wolf symbolizes bravery
column8: as in the association with the hunter or the warrior in folklore.  They are a vital part of any ecosystem they are part of
column9: maintaining a delicate balance of other animals such as hares
column10: beaver
column11: and caribou.  Without them
column12: populations of other creatures would go unchecked and the result to the ecosystem would be disastrous.  Studies have shown that without wolves
column13: some areas experience an overpopulation of beavers
column14: and ultimately
column15: rivers and watersheds are permanently changed. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/pack-arctic-wolves-settle-nap-155008859.html#Wg3LSz2lo

column1: 2020-12-27 21:41:53#sport#Nonverbal Boy Receives Surprise Gifts From UPS Drivers#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/nonverbal-boy-receives-surprise-gifts-214153404.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/27/5fe900d65068c33bdc2cc0f7/5fe900d65068c33bdc2cc0f8_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Jace
column2: a nine-year-old UPS enthusiast with Angelman Syndrome
column3: was delighted to receive a surprise gift from his local UPS drivers in Bellevue
column4: Ohio
column5: on December 23. Brandy Rohlf
column6: Jace’s mother
column7: shared footage of the heartwarming encounter to Facebook. “[Jace] waits every day for the UPS guys to drive by
column8: ” she wrote in her post.  “If he is not outside waiting for them he sits at the window and watches for them.  They ALWAYS honk and wave and look for him in the window.  Today they stopped by and gave Jace a gift because they noticed his excitement when they drive by. ”Rohlf told Storyful that Angelman Syndrome
column9: a rare neurogenetic disorder
column10: causes developmental disabilities
column11: difficulty with motor function and speech
column12: and “a very happy and excitable demeanor. ”“The driver’s wife sent me a message and told me they can’t wait to go by our house
column13: ” Rohlf told Storyful. “It’s the highlight of their day too.  They look forward to it just as much as Jace does. ”The drivers gave Jace a UPS-branded hat
column14: a toy truck
column15: and some candy
column16: Rohlf said.  Credit: Brandy Rohlf via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/nonverbal-boy-receives-surprise-gifts-214153404.html#JWF9r5sWg

column1: 2020-12-26 06:07:38#sport#This Ancient City Should Be Your First Stop in Spain Post-Pandemic#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/ancient-city-first-stop-spain-060738482.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/sF96zNtUcH1B4lRMKhQv4g--~B/aD02NTg7dz0xMTcwO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/https://media.zenfs.com/en-US/thedailybeast.com/1ea149113cb8795359ae05e46ebfd374#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#This is the latest edition of our twice-a-month series on underrated destinations
column2: It’s Still a Big World. Ask a well-traveled friend where you should vacation in Spain post pandemic
column3: and you’ll likely get an earful on Barcelona’s dreamy architecture
column4: San Sebastián’s epic pintxo crawls
column5: and Sevilla’s foot-stomping flamenco tablaos.  But here’s my hot tip as a six-year Spain transplant who travels to pay the bills: Some of the most exciting news in Spanish travel for 2021 is out of Cáceres
column6: a sleepy medieval city located 180 miles west of Madrid. I first visited Cáceres in 2017
column7: lured by the promise of porcine delights (acorn-fed ham! spicy patatera sausage!)
column8: orange tree-shaded plazas
column9: and one of the best-preserved medieval enclaves in Europe.  Approaching the city
column10: I remember gasping at the skyline
column11: all right angles with its low whitewashed houses and 30-some towers
column12: some nearly 1
column13: 000 years old.  Brick steeples and cupolas shot up between them
column14: lending an aristocratic grandeur to the place.  Storks soared overhead. My first walk through the Ciudad Monumental
column15: or Old Town
column16: revealed sinuous streets lined with mansions
column17: churches
column18: and monasteries built from stone
column19: a foreboding sepia-tinged maze built to last.  Perusing the placards on each historical facade as if I were touring a museum
column20: I struggled to find a single building newer than the 16th century.  Ornate coats of arms hovering above doorways bore the seals of fairytale surnames that were fun to say aloud: Godoy
column21: Saavedra
column22: Golfín
column23: and Ovando-Mogollón.  Everything was preserved as if in amber.  The only glaring signs of modernity came in the form of film crew vans and extension cords: The Old Town was being used as a Game of Thrones filming location. Cáceres peaked early and then sort of calcified.  Though the Romans
column25: and Moors laid the city’s groundwork
column26: erecting towers and installing cisterns (the one beneath the Museum of Cáceres is worth a visit)
column27: the city’s heyday was between the late 15th and mid-17th centuries.  It was during that period that explorers from the surrounding region—such as Hernán Cortés
column29: and Francisco Pizarro—brought back shiploads of plundered riches from the so-called New World to fund the city’s opulent constructions. But then
column32: Cáceres was caught in the crossfire of a protracted war over Portugal
column33: forcing many residents to flee.  By the turn of the 20th century
column35: sparsely populated backwater ravaged by centuries of latifundism and neglect.  People only began giving Cáceres a second look in 1967
column36: when the Council of Europe declared it the third most significant monumental ensemble on the continent
column37: bested only by Tallinn and Prague.  UNESCO named it a World Heritage Site in 1986. The irony of Cáceres’s dark chapter is that it may have saved the Ciudad Monumental from ruin.  Had the city remained prosperous through the centuries
column38: its Old Town would’ve been wrecked to make way for newer buildings. As the weekend unfolded
column39: I was struck by how well suited Cáceres was to excursions from Madrid.  It had it all: stunning churches (I’ll never forget the view from the bell tower of Iglesia de San Francisco Javier)
column41: and hotels for every budget.  Toledo and Segovia are the most popular field trips from the Spanish capital
column42: but while fascinating in their own right
column43: they’re in-your-face touristy (think magnets and postcards in every corner shop).  Cáceres
column45: felt like a real vacation—it oozed Spanish history and culture without a tourbus in sight. After that trip
column46: I talked up Cáceres to anyone who’d listen
column47: but I didn’t have a pressing reason to return until earlier this month
column48: when I got wind of a flurry of news developments: a hotel opening
column51: and a new restaurant run by one of Spain’s top chefs.  Finally
column53: Cáceres would get the international buzz it deserves.  But then it dawned on me: With leisure travel at a standstill and foreigners largely banned from visiting Spain
column54: Cáceres’s biggest year in over a decade could potentially go unnoticed abroad
column55: another blow to the already-hamstrung tourism industry.  Determined to spread the gospel
column58: and set out to see what there was to look forward to in Cáceres in the After Times. After ditching my suitcase at the NH Collection Cáceres Palacio de Oquendo
column59: a reliable mid-range hotel housed in a 16th-century stone palace
column60: I zigzagged up into the Old Town.  It was pin-drop quiet—no cars
column62: just the squeak of my shoes on the wet cobblestones.  My first stop was the Helga Alvear Contemporary Art Museum.  When I came here in 2017
column63: I left scratching my head: The low-ceilinged medieval building housed confusingly conceptual art (a pyramid of multicolored balls
column64: garments pinned to a folded rug)
column65: and the collection felt clunky and out of place.  The German art collector has since thrown money at the problem to the tune of €10 million.  Tuñón Architects (of MUSAC fame) are behind the renovation
column69: I could make out Tuñón’s signature wooden slats peeking above the scaffolding.  “It’s going to feel like a completely new museum
column70: ” a representative told me over the phone
column71: adding that it would open “sometime” in 2021.  “The new space will allow us to finally showcase large-format pieces from the collection that we weren’t previously able to display. ”The Helga Alvear is a five-minute walk from the heart of the old Judería
column73: a tangle of narrow streets and white single-story houses huddled around the Ermita de San Antonio
column74: originally the main synagogue.  “Jewish Cáceres” is one of several new niche-interest tours that the local tourist office will launch in 2021
column77: ” and a route hitting the city’s most scenic viewpoints.  (Stop by the tourist office on the Plaza Mayor to inquire about tour schedules. )But perhaps the most thrilling developments of all are in Cáceres’s hospitality sector.  To be fair
column78: there was already plenty to rave about: The city is home to one of Spain’s most exclusive design hotels
column80: presided over by Cáceres-born partners (in both business and love) Toño Pérez and José Polo.  Atrio’s rooms are dramatically lit and bear original works by Warhol
column84: Pérez runs a two-Michelin-star kitchen where Extremaduran delicacies like lomo doblao (Ibérico pork loin confited lard) and torta del Casar (a creamy
column85: grassy ewe’s-milk cheese) are woven into tasting menus that will have you crunching on a tapioca “butterfly” filled with salmon mousse one minute and braised partridge draped with black truffles the next. The duo’s latest passion project
column86: slated to open in the second half of 2021
column87: is an 11-suite hotel catty-corner from Atrio called Casa Palacio Paredes Saavedra.  “It’s shaping up phenomenally
column88: ” Polo told me over coffee and meringues.  “The accommodations are going to be enormous.  One of the suites has a 215-square-foot bathroom—that
column90: is true luxury. ” Evidently Tuñón Arquitectos has had a busy year.  In addition to the Helga Alvear
column91: they’re undertaking the gut renovation and redesign of this 16th-century mansion.  When it’s finished
column92: guests paying upwards of €800 a night will be able to enjoy amenities like his-and-hers showers
column95: and deep-sink tubs cut from single slabs of Italian marble.  There are plans to turn the original subterranean cistern into a candlelit sauna and hammam. Pérez’s food is peerless in Cáceres
column96: but cheap it ain’t.  So when the couple announced that they were taking over Torre de Sande
column97: the middling casual restaurant next door
column98: and opening an informal Extremaduran asador (grill restaurant) in its place
column99: locals jumped for joy.  The space
column101: is absolutely stunning.  Torre de Sande is named for the 14th-century tower it occupies
column102: so you can imagine the bones: stone pillars
column105: Pérez and Polo rent the place from a viscount (!)
column106: who gave his blessing for them to queer-eye the place—hola
column107: deliciously dim track lighting and black marble tabletops.  Covid willing
column108: you’ll be able to enjoy Pérez’s smoky roast meats and locavore tapas outside on the ivy-fringed patio come summer.  But whether a trip to Spain is in the cards next year or in 10
column109: Cáceres will doubtlessly still be there
column110: standing proud. Where to StayAtrio is one of the most exalted hotels in Spain—with rates to match.  More affordable launching pads include the NH Collection Cáceres Palacio de Oquendo
column111: situated 100 yards from the bustling Plaza Mayor
column113: a few blocks north of the Old Town.  Both hotels stand out for their genial service and hearty breakfasts yet are equally a bit frayed at the edges (chipped paint and flimsy towels—that sort of thing). Where to EatBeyond Atrio and Torre de Sande
column114: there are few truly great restaurants inside the Old Town.  Take a six-minute taxi ride to Javier Martín in the Nuevo Cáceres neighborhood
column115: and you’ll be rewarded with shockingly well-priced tasting menus and ample à la carte options ranging from Ibérico pork carpaccio to creamy lobster rice to Almadraba tuna tataki.  Far more casual
column118: a third-generation bar that churns out unapologetically old-school raciones like white gazpacho
column121: a zippy Extremaduran salad of smoky roasted peppers and good Spanish tuna finished with a garlicky vinaigrette and a few flicks of parsley. Read more at The Daily Beast. Get our top stories in your inbox every day.  Sign up now!Daily Beast Membership: Beast Inside goes deeper on the stories that matter to you.  Learn more. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/ancient-city-first-stop-spain-060738482.html#2rFdilOZk

column1: 2020-12-18 20:55:21#sport#London Delivery Man Brings Some Groovy Christmas Cheer#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/london-delivery-man-brings-groovy-205521467.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/18/5fdd1791e61260769200fadc/5fdd1793f7a4f600012d1bbb_480x480_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#A home security camera captured heartwarming footage of a DPD delivery man dancing and singing as he dropped off a package at a home in London on December 8. Bexleyheath
column2: London
column3: resident Gemma McPherson was expecting a pair of shoes to be delivered when she got a notification on her phone that her front doorbell camera had been activated. “I knew someone was coming down the pathway.  I headed to the front door and I could hear what sounded like drums and singing
column4: ” McPherson told Storyful. Her son answered the door and collected the package from the deliveryman
column5: said thank you
column6: and sent him on his way. “Because I could hear something I decided to check on my Ring doorbell camera.  And to my surprise it was him
column7: the delivery driver
column8: he was so lovely
column9: happy
column10: festive
column11: and cheery
column12: ” McPherson said. This video shows the delivery driver
column13: Arnaud Helderal
column14: walking up the driveway
column15: singing a Christmas tune to himself as he taps on the package like a drum and dances a bit. McPherson posted the video to a local Facebook page and several people commented sharing similar experiences
column16: and it became clear that Helderal had unknowingly been spreading holiday cheer to residences all around Bexleyheath. McPherson called DPD to let them know how pleased she was with her driver
column17: and that she wanted to nominate him for an award to thank him for his incredible service. “The very next day after receiving the award of recognition
column18: he turned up at my doorstep and gave my son who answered the door that day the mug he received from work
column19: ” she told Storyful. “We have seen him since and he has said how overwhelmed he is and how thankful he is
column20: ” she says
column21: and that he has even stopped by since just to say hello.  Credit: Gemma McPherson via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/london-delivery-man-brings-groovy-205521467.html#0XQURv9iK

column3: Egg and Potato Biscuit Sandwich Ingredients 4 biscuits (sliced in half) 4 large slices of leftover ham 4 slices pepper jack cheese For Potato Pancakes: 3 cups leftover mash potatoes 3 scallions chopped 3 tablespoons vegetable oil (frying) For the eggs: 8 eggs 2 tablespoons butter 1 teaspoon salt/pepper 1 tablespoon sour cream 1 tablespoon chives For Leftover Cranberry Mayo: 1/2 cup mayo 2 tablespoons cranberry sauce 1 teaspoon apple cider vinegar Directions Make the potato pancakes by mixing scallions and leftover mashed potatoes.  Then divide into four pancakes (make slightly bigger then bottom of biscuit) and fry in pan with oil two minutes per side. #https://www.yahoo.com/gma/potato-pancake-egg-cheese-breakfast-104744796.html#ypllIiKBz

column1: 2020-12-22 16:00:03#sport#World's smallest turtle gets help to clean food off his face#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/worlds-smallest-turtle-gets-help-160003202.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/22/5fe21976e612607692010899/5fe21976e61260769201089a_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#The black-breasted leaf turtle is one of the smallest turtle species on earth
column2: growing to a mere 11cm in length (4. 5 inches).  They are a strikingly beautiful turtle with a shell that resembles a fallen leaf
column3: and large owl-like eyes.  Capable of watching two things at once
column4: their large eyes provide this turtle with very keen vision.  They inhabit the forest floor of heavily canopied areas in Vietnam and South East Asia
column5: eating worms
column6: insects
column7: and fallen fruit.  Visual perception seems to be important to these small turtles as they readily feed on fruits and vegetables that are red
column8: or brightly coloured.  They also seem to prefer overly ripe fruit
column9: possibly also due to colour.  Although this turtle prefers to live near fresh water such as streams
column10: it is a terrestrial turtle and does not live in the water.  These turtles reside at the Toronto Zoo in an elaborate and sizable enclosure that has fresh water
column11: leaf substrate and a healthy population of these turtles for socialization.  Highly praised for both the living conditions for zoo families and their efforts to promote and fund conservation efforts world wide
column12: the Toronto Zoo is an excellent organization.  The turtle in this video has just been fed.  Although his friends have also had their share
column13: the lingering piece of his lunch on his beak has attracted the attention of one of his buddies.  He makes a beeline for the one with the food and helps him out by grabbing the morsel of food for himself.  The adorable little faces and expressive eyes make these turtles a joy to watch. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/worlds-smallest-turtle-gets-help-160003202.html#n2G2fxlxv

column1: 2020-12-21 23:03:39#sport#Festive Goat Makes Eating Peanut Shells Look Like a Good Idea#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/festive-goat-makes-eating-peanut-230339569.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/21/5fe12a87e75f6906e8450cdd/5fe12a87e75f6906e8450cde_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#An adorable goat from Tennessee got to taste peanuts for the first time on December 13 – and seemed to think the shells were just as yummy as the nuts themselves. Moona Ruth is one of several goats cared for and frequently dressed up by Tennessee resident Britney.  Britney runs a YouTube channel called Goat Life where she documents the different themed outfits they wear and the fun they get up to. 2020-12-21 16:00:03#sport#Laughter & friendship is the same in any language
column2: even in a remote world#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/laughter-friendship-same-language-even-160003751.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/21/5fe0c8063b6d0e20a85373f8/5fe0c8063b6d0e20a85373f9_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"One of the biggest thrills of travel is meeting and interacting with people from different worlds and different cultures.  These tourists were aboard the FV FeBrina
column3: a scuba diving liveaboard that took them around the remote waters in Papua New Guinea.  Exploring Kimbe Bay
column4: they were treated to some to the most spectacular scuba diving in the world.  The coral reefs and ocean life are unrivaled in their beauty and diversity and the colours and sights beneath the waves are breathtaking.  But when they came up from an hour of exploration beneath the waves
column5: they were surprised to be met by a few families from one of the remote islands.  They live off the land in a very traditional way with very little influence from the outside world and with very little exposure to technology.  Paddling out from their village in dugout canoes
column6: the women brought fresh produce and coconuts.  In a form of commerce that is centuries old
column7: the boat crew also provided the villagers with some essentials such as rice and cooking supplies.  They regularly donate books and school supplies to these island people as well
column8: helping them with their own system of education.  The ocean provides the people of the islands with a lot of food also.  They spear fish and harvest sea cucumbers
column9: crabs
column10: and other edible creatures.  Life in this world has not changed much for the people in the past 100 years.  In fact
column11: many remote highlands areas of Papua New Guinea made their first contact with white people from the outside world as recently as the 1930s.  A small group of prospectors were among the first people to make contact with isolated civilizations.  It had been thought that the geography of these areas presented such difficulty that people could not survive in the highlands.  This isolation of the peoples has led to the diversity in language
column12: with Papua New Guinea having more than 826 separate languages.  These kids were fascinated by the very pale skin of the tourists on board the boat.  Although there was no ability to communicate with a mutual language
column13: smiles
column14: laughter
column15: gestures and small gifts made interaction easy enough
column16: and extremely enjoyable.  The villagers provided Dave with coconut and a delicious seaweed that went well together.  Dave entertained them with backflips of the stern and with his iPhone
column17: which they used to take group selfies.  Kristy joked with one of the mothers as they all laughed at the ""kids""
column18: including Dave and she shared her bag of candies with them.  While we can easily focus on the things that make us all different
column19: it is equally important to focus on what makes us the same.  As these new friends demonstrate
column20: laughter is the universal language. "#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/laughter-friendship-same-language-even-160003751.html#jHhPb5tqJ

column2: pear and port trifle recipe#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/cranberry-pear-port-trifle-recipe-144322799.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/R7HOLKH7tV30dQ5jcgUtdg--~B/aD0zODc7dz02MTk7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/8db2527f3de5b7eb3ae99db8a95662c9#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#To savour this at its best
column3: start making it a day ahead.  Prep time: 30 minutes
column4: plus 30 minutes soaking | Cooking time: 40 minutes SERVES Eight INGREDIENTS 200ml port 200ml red wine 2 broad strips lemon rind 100g granulated sugar 1 star anise 5cm piece cinnamon stick 4 fat pears
column5: peeled
column6: quartered and cored 200g fresh cranberries 75g dried cranberries 250g sponge cake 125ml port 500g good-quality fresh custard To finish 50ml port 25g dried cranberries 300ml double or whipping cream ½ tsp vanilla extract Icing sugar
column7: to taste 2 tbsp roughly chopped toasted walnuts or hazelnuts METHOD Put the port
column8: wine
column9: 100ml water
column10: lemon rind
column11: sugar
column12: star anise and cinnamon stick into a saucepan large enough to hold the quartered pears in a single layer.  Bring to the boil
column13: turn down the heat and simmer for five minutes.  Add the pears and poach until they are tender – this can take anything from 15 to 30 minutes
column14: depending on their ripeness – turning them over periodically.  Test with a fine skewer to check whether they are cooked.  If you can leave them soaking in the liquid overnight
column15: they’ll darken and become even more fragrant.  Remove the pears with a slotted spoon and put them into a bowl.  Discard the spices.  Make the cranberry mixture
column16: allowing yourself plenty of time for it to cool.  Put the fresh and dried cranberries into a medium saucepan with the poaching liquor from the pears and bring to the boil.  Turn down the heat and simmer for about six minutes.  The liquid should be thick and syrupy
column17: and about two-thirds of the cranberries will have popped.  Leave to cool completely.  You will end up with a rough purée.  Cut the sponge cake into slices.  Layer everything in a glass serving-bowl
column18: soaking well in port as you go
column19: starting with half of the sponge slices
column20: then half of the pears
column21: half the cranberry purée and half the custard.  Repeat so that you have two layers of each.  Cover with clingfilm and
column22: if you wish
column23: chill until the next day.  Bring the port and dried cranberries to the boil
column24: and immediately take off the heat.  Leave to soak for 30 minutes
column25: or until completely cool.  Drain.  Just before serving
column27: and add the vanilla and icing sugar to taste.  Spread this over the top of the trifle and sprinkle on the nuts and the soaked cranberries. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/cranberry-pear-port-trifle-recipe-144322799.html#bHuN549uC

column1: 2020-12-20 13:00:03#sport#Kindly tourist shows compassion for hungry street cow in India#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/kindly-tourist-shows-compassion-hungry-130003293.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/20/5fdf4cb53b6d0e20a8537032/5fdf4cb53b6d0e20a8537033_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#India is often referred to as a country of contrasts.  or a country of extremes.  There is great beauty and rich history
column2: and only a few steps away
column3: there is great poverty and hardship.  This is true for the animals here
column4: as well as for the people and there are more than 5 million stray cows that wander the streets.  They seek food in composts and garbage bins and on vacant lots where a few blades of grass grow.  The cows are sacred to most of the people in India and their faith prohibits them from eating the meat of cows.  Impoverished farmers cannot afford to feed or care for the animals that they rely on for milk and the cows wander
column5: eating what little they can find.  Unfortunately
column6: cows often ingest garbage and plastic and their digestive tracts become blocked
column7: causing them to become malnourished.  This prevents them from producing milk and they become more of a burden to the farmers than they can manage.  Farmers have little choice and they release the cows to fend for themselves.  The cows roam free
column8: often relying on the kindness of strangers.  They are fed bread and table scraps by those who can afford to pass on some kindness for these gentle beasts.  This Canadian tourist has watched this dairy cow as she wanders
column9: obviously looking for a meal.  She takes pictures of the unusual sight
column10: but she cannot walk away without doing something to help.  She finds a nearby vendor who is selling alfalfa
column11: a sweet grass that is high in protein and other nutrients.  She buys two large bunches and then goes back to find the cow in an alcove where it seems to spend the nights.  The cow is quite happy to munch away on the alfalfa and this kindly Canadian leaves the both bunches at her feet to be enjoyed at her own pace.  The dilemma in India continues to get worse as conditions for farmers get more unmanageable.  the number of stray cows increases constantly.  Many organizations collect donations to help provide the cows with food and a place to live so they will not suffer and present a hazard to motorists in the busy streets. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/kindly-tourist-shows-compassion-hungry-130003293.html#xHlqAeoq5

2020-12-19 12:57:52#sport#This easy mince pie recipe has the most decadent twist#https://uk.style.yahoo.com/easy-mince-pie-recipe-most-125752131.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/XoCMJBEUaDyUIPM.chwKkQ--~B/aD02MDA7dz00NTA7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en/hello__263/f7d020f9f45df3425552d606c407576d#en#1.0#uk.style.yahoo.com#Nothing says Christmas quite like the humble mince pie.  If you've tried every version from M&S; to Lidl and still aren't satisfied
column2: we recommend baking your own at home.  Look no further than this mince pie recipe with orange and cinnamon crumble topping - the perfect twist on the classic festive snack.  The delicious treats serve 12 and only take 20 minutes to make - they couldn't be easier.  MORE: Mary Berry's traditional Christmas cake recipe is a total showstopper Mince Pies with Orange and Cinnamon Crumble ToppingPreparation and cooking time: 20 mins
column3: Serves 12 INGREDIENTS: * 375g shortcrust pastry * 250g good quality mincemeat * 50g plain flour * 4 tbsp demerara sugar * 40g butter * finely grated zest of ½ orange * 1 tsp ground cinnamon INSTRUCTIONS: Step 1Pre-heat the oven to 200ºC/fan 180ºC fan oven/gas 6.  Step 2Thinly roll out the pastry and using a 7. 5-9cm pastry cutter
column4: cut out as many disks as you can
column5: re-rolling the trimmings as you go.  Press the disks into the holes of one or two 12 hole patty tins. YUM: Peter Andre's wife Emily makes the most decadent Christmas dessert Step 3Spoon a couple of teaspoons of mincemeat into each pastry case and set aside.  Step 4To make the crumble topping
column6: rub together the flour
column7: demerara sugar
column8: butter
column9: orange zest and cinnamon until you have a chunky crumble mixture.  Scatter over the top of the mincemeat and place in the oven for around 15 minutes or until the mince pies are golden and the tops are crisp.  Step 5Remove from the oven and leave to cool for a few minutes before taking out of the tins.  Cool on a wire rack and dust with icing sugar to serve. column144: Nanjiani wrote.  ""My dad has these socks. "" 44 Serena Williams gets a COVID test from a Disney princessThis year has been an interesting one for kids
column146: Olympia.  Mom shared a video of her daughter playing the most 2020 game of make-believe: pretending to give her mom a COVID test—which she calls a ""coconut test""—while wearing a Snow White dress.  She counts to ten before removing it from her nose and everything.  Future doctor? 45 Angela Kinsey is a real cat ladyLike Angela Kinsey's character on The Office
column148: she's all about her cats.  In one of the most memorable scenes of the series
column149: Angela tosses one of her furry friends through the Dunder Mifflin ceiling
column150: and it seems that the actor's cats tend to get in some compromising positions
column151: too.  Case in point: This photo of Kinsey's cat
column153: who has moved into a dollhouse. ""The cats are in rare form today
column154: she wrote in the caption.  ""I have found Oreo in the hall closet
column155: on top of the pantry shelf and now this…"" 46 Jenny Mollen gets creative with her Elf on a ShelfThanks to the popularity of Elf on a Shelf
column156: plenty of parents spend a good chunk of the holiday season posing these ubiquitous figurines.  Jenny Mollen went the extra mile to make sure her kids with husband Jason Biggs
column158: would be impressed.  Here we have the elves acting out the opening scene from Jaws—or as Mollen describes it
column159: ""a children's holiday classic. "" 47 Sarah Michelle Gellar shows us where it all went wrongIt wasn't until July that Sarah Michelle Gellar realized that she had a bad omen about 2020 right at the beginning.  She said received this 2019 New Year's Eve hat instead of the 2020 she ordered at the end of last year.  ""Maybe someone was trying to tell us to not even attempt 2020
column160: she wrote on Instagram.  ""Wish I had listened. "" 48 Gabrielle Union's daughter isn't having itGabrielle Union and Dwyane Wade's daughter Kaavia didn't seem too thankful this Thanksgiving.  In this video from their family dinner
column161: someone—probably her dad—reaches out to clean up her face with a napkin
column162: and she couldn't possibly be more annoyed.  Even better? The fact that her shirt very clearly proclaims that she's ""not interested. "" 49 Chrissy Teigen won't drop this jokeThe joke that John Legend looks almost exactly like the animated aardvark Arthur is one that's been around a while
column164: Chrissy Teigen shows no signs of letting it go yet.  Back in April
column165: she shared this photo of their son
column169: ""Miles with daddy and Elmo. "" 50 Sebastian Stan pays tribute to Gossip GirlKnown more recently for his role of Bucky Barnes in the Marvel Cinematic Universe
column170: Sebastian Stan isn't one to forget his roots—roots like playing Carter Baizen in the teen drama Gossip Girl.  The actor marked the September anniversary of the show's premiere by sitting down to the pilot with a glass of wine and logging his visceral reactions for Twitter.  ""It was the best of times and it was the best of times

column1: 2020-12-14 06:02:00#sport#University surprises graduate by giving her service dog an honorary degree#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/university-surprises-graduate-giving-her-060200421.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/jO3KjkC499dQwb29A4dQdA--~B/aD01NjA7dz04NDA7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en/the_week_574/1670c0296bceac1db611753f76e8ed91#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"When Maggie Leptrone graduated from the University of West Georgia earlier this month with her degree in nursing
column2: so did her labradoodle
column3: Mona. Leptrone has Type 1 diabetes
column4: and says Mona
column5: who was trained by the Diabetic Alert Dogs of America to detect low blood sugar levels
column6: saved her life one night when her blood sugar dropped to a dangerously low level.  Mona goes everywhere with Leptrone
column7: and attended all of her classes and labs and other on-campus activities. At commencement
column8: organizers gave Leptrone a small cap for Mona to wear during the event
column9: but Leptrone told the Atlanta Journal-Constitution she had no idea the university was going to recognize Mona until they awarded her an honorary dog-ree: her very own Bark-chelor of Science in Nursing. Leptrone
column10: who has accepted a job as an intensive care unit nurse in Douglasville
column11: Georgia
column12: told the Journal-Constitution she thought it was wonderful that her school included Mona during the graduation festivities.  ""I'm just hoping that it shows other people like me who have a service dog that they can still obtain a high level of education and do what they've always dreamed of doing with their lives
column13: she said. More stories from theweek. com The GOP has 1 last shot to contest Trump's loss — and a 'negative percent' chance of success Donald Trump's defeat is good.  Why does it feel so bad? Fauci: Americans without underlying conditions could get COVID-19 vaccine by late March
column14: early April"#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/university-surprises-graduate-giving-her-060200421.html#GenkcpEUR

2020-12-17 22:00:12#sport#Cute leopard cub loves to play with his mother's tail#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/cute-leopard-cub-loves-play-220012879.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/17/5fdbd6ea5068c33bdc2c9c0b/5fdbd6ea5068c33bdc2c9c0c_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Finding a leopard in the wild while on a safari is always a special occasion.  Finding a leopard mother and her cub in the wild is a priceless
column2: once in a lifetime
column3: experience.  I recently had the rare opportunity to film the adorable moments of a playful leopard cub
column4: totally amused by its mother’s tail.  The leopard is one of the most elusive animals in the African bush.  This shy and solitary big cat is part of the so called Big five animals in Africa that also includes lion
column5: buffalo
column6: rhino and elephant.  The leopard is by far the most difficult to find and see.  The leopard relies on its camouflage and stealth to bring down prey that can range from mice to large antelope species.  It was during a recent safari in the Kruger National Park that we were lucky enough to come across a female leopard
column7: lying alone in the sand of a dry riverbed.  We were absolutely ecstatic with our find.  We all whipped out our cameras and started filming and taking pictures.  It was not long before we were absolutely exhilarated by the fact that the female leopard had the most adorable cub.  Out of nowhere
column8: the cute leopard cub appeared.  The appearance of the cub took us all by surprise and we couldn’t believe that we were actually sitting with two leopards in front of us.  Leopards are solitary predators and do not like to be seen.  If you are lucky enough to find a leopard in the wild
column9: it will always be alone.  Only under rare circumstances will you get to see more than one leopard together such as this one with the mother and her cub and when a male and female meet up to mate.  The moments that followed between this leopard cub and its mother was filled with playfulness and motherly love.  When the leopard cub appeared from the bush
column10: it was immediately interested in its mother’s tail.  It was so cute to watch how the cub’s hunting instincts was triggered by its mother’s moving tail.  Every time the female leopard would move her tail
column11: the cub would playfully paw at her tail while trying to grab it.  This playful behaviour continued for a while until the cub became bored with its mother’s tail.  The leopard cub decided it was time to snuggle up against its mother before falling asleep.  We decided that we would not overstay our welcome and left the two leopards in peace. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/cute-leopard-cub-loves-play-220012879.html#5lqBORhDj

2020-12-15 08:48:41#sport#US woman captures rare sighting of moose triplets in backyard#https://www.msn.com/en-gb/sport/other/us-woman-captures-rare-sighting-of-moose-triplets-in-backyard/vi-BB1bWcm7#https://www.msn.com/en-gb/sport/other/us-woman-captures-rare-sighting-of-moose-triplets-in-backyard/vi-BB1bWcm7#en#1.0#www.msn.com#"A homeowner in Alaska managed to capture footage of a mother moose and her triplets
column2: an incredibly rare occurrence in nature.  Kathy Nuttle
column3: who moved to Alaska with her family from New York eight years ago
column4: was preparing a meal for a small gathering when she spotted the moose with her three babies on November 30.  The chances of multiple births
column5: usually twins
column6: increases when a moose cow is well-nourished and safe during pregnancy.  Triplets
column7: however
column8: are an extremely rare sighting.  Speaking about the video Kathy said: ""We looked out our kitchen window to see a moose mother with three babies - probably born May 2020.  ""Triplets are very rare
column9: so I gathered my camera and went out to our back deck and took the video and several pictures.  ""We have moose in our yard often
column10: but not a mother with three babies. """#https://www.msn.com/en-gb/sport/other/us-woman-captures-rare-sighting-of-moose-triplets-in-backyard/vi-BB1bWcm7#onwKsOjrJ

column4: the swaddles with oversized bows and their matching caps were crocheted for the infants by talented nurse Caitlin Pechin. “UPMC Magee’s tradition of dressing newborns in festive outfits brings some much-needed smiles this holiday season

column7: said. “While so many aspects of life have changed this year

column10: during a trying year

2020-12-13 18:47:36#sport#Britain to build 'comet chaser' spacecraft to help find out how life formed on Earth#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/britain-build-comet-chaser-spacecraft-184736082.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/rCuzolJZB4Btg8Dq4qVB7A--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMjUw/https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/bU2upqQFVnVmAuKVvZcs8g--~B/aD0xNTYzO3c9MjUwMTthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/a0e4b1240b4fb20989162968b5017d2a#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Britain is to build a “comet chaser” spacecraft to help find the origins of the universe and life on earth.  The mission
column2: to boldly go where no probe has gone before
column3: will track and travel to an as-yet unidentified comet and map it in 3D for the first time.  Once in space the craft will lie in wait
column4: potentially for years
column5: until a cosmic candidate is spotted by astronomers on Earth.  From there it will set out to intercept it
column6: deploying two smaller probes which will take readings and beam the data back to the main hub.  Though the process could only take a few hours
column7: it is thought to shed light on the conditions in our universe more than four billion years ago.  The Telegraph understands that numerous countries applied to run the project and it is viewed by officials as a major coup for the UK scientific community.  Thales Alenia Space
column8: a company with three sites in the UK and nearly 200 employees won the contract to design the mothership for the Comet Interceptor mission
column9: with the two smaller probes made in Japan.  It is the first of the European Space Agency’s new class of “fast” missions where light equipment can hitchhike into space on an already scheduled launch.  This mission was originally proposed by a team led by UK academics from University College London and the University of Edinburgh.  Amanda Solloway
column10: the science minister said: “The UK’s space industry is thriving and this out-of-this-world mission is testament to our world-leading expertise.  “I am very proud that scientists and engineers in Bristol and Harwell will be designing the Comet Interceptor spacecraft – their incredible work will not only further our understanding of the evolution of comets but help unlock the mysteries of the universe. ” Scientists are likely to target a comet from the Oort Cloud
column11: a band of icy debris which lies between the sun and our next nearest star.  This cloud contains matter formed during the birth of our solar system
column12: which will have been left intact as it has not been vaporised by rays from the sun.  This means that the probes will be able to study the composition of the comet to evaluate whether similar specimens may have brought water to Earth in the past.  Life on our planet could not exist without water
column13: and it is thought by many that comets may have been responsible for bringing that water to our planet.  Andrew Stanniland
column14: CEO of Thales Alenia Space in the UK said: “I am delighted ESA has once again placed its trust in our scientists and engineers at Thales Alenia Space in the UK who have excellent heritage from previous scientific missions such as Giotto and Rosetta.  “We all look forward to supporting this exciting and unprecedented scientific mission to uncover more information about the origins of our Universe. ”#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/britain-build-comet-chaser-spacecraft-184736082.html#qwAjDsZPT

column1: 2020-12-11 10:56:40#sport#Dog Rescued From Jaws of Alligator Gets New Job With Sheriff#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/dog-rescued-jaws-alligator-gets-105640936.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/11/5fd3518c63753c286a68d9e9/5fd3518c63753c286a68d9ea_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#A puppy whose owner saved him from the jaws of an alligator in Estero
column2: Florida
column3: was recently made a member of the Lee County Sheriff’s Office Deputy Dogs program. Gunner
column4: a four-month-old Cavalier King Charles spaniel
column5: was rescued from an alligator attack in October when his owner Richard Wilbanks jumped into a pond to save him. Video of the incident shows Wilbanks pulling an alligator’s jaws apart
column6: freeing Gunner. Gunner was this week officially deputized as a member of the Lee County Sheriff’s Office Deputy Dogs program. “Do you swear to uphold the constitutional law for the Lee County Sheriff’s Office? This is a big day
column7: OK.  You are going to be a detective now
column8: ” Sheriff Carmine Marceno said to Gunner while pinning a badge on his harness. The Deputy Dogs Pets on Patrol initiative “encourages pet owners to pay closer attention to suspicious activity while out with their pets and report concerns to the Lee County Sheriff’s Office
column9: ” the sheriff’s office says.  Credit: Lee County Sheriff’s Office via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/dog-rescued-jaws-alligator-gets-105640936.html#25D79XZdN

column1: 2020-12-08 12:30:40#sport#Mount Everest grows 34 inches as China and Nepal remeasure top of the world#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/mount-everest-grows-34-inches-123040037.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/mY8uYiZRQOVxI.SMP4.90w--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMjUw/https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/pkaYSjSVn1jfq0.hwN9inQ--~B/aD0xNTYzO3c9MjUwMTthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/e3823422f16ba3ce811dea010ef2e41a#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#The world's tallest mountain has become a little bit taller after China and Nepal remeasured Mount Everest.  New calculations put the top of the world 86cm (34in) higher than previously recognised
column2: measuring in at 8
column4: 032 feet).  The joint declaration by two national survey teams also settled a long disagreement between neighbouring China and Nepal on Everest's height.  Until this week
column5: Nepal had judged the mountain to be 8
column7: while China considered it four metres lower.  Both sides decided to check the mountain's height after speculation that a 2015 earthquake in the region had shifted tectonic plates under Everest and global warming may have thinned snow caps.  Nepal had at first planned to conduct the measurement alone
column8: but a joint project was convened under the banner of “eternal friendship” after Chinese President Xi Jinping visited the Himalayan nation in 2019.  Nepalese surveyors climbed the mountain more than a year ago to take new measurements
column9: in the first such expedition by the nation.  Chinese surveyors made their ascent in May 2020
column10: becoming the only team to reach the summit this year after the Covid-19 pandemic closed the mountain to climbers.  The teams used a mixture of GPS data and trigonometric calculations from lower mountains to make their new estimate. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/mount-everest-grows-34-inches-123040037.html#t8sqYPHSs

column1: 2020-12-11 22:00:11#sport#Lion cub adamantly seeks attention from his sleepy father#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/lion-cub-adamantly-seeks-attention-220011355.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/11/5fd3ed20f1b75b5bf1e5b1d5/5fd3ed20f1b75b5bf1e5b1d6_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Baby animals will always have a soft spot in most people’s hearts.  Seeing baby animals in the African wild is always a special occasion.  It was during a safari in the Kruger National Park that this adorable moment between a lion cub and his father was captured.  It was like watching a possible real-life scene from the Lion King movie with Simba jumping on top of Mufasa
column2: looking for attention.  We recently had incredible luck on our side during a safari when we came across a large pride of lions resting in the shade.  Lions are big sleepers and they can easily spend twenty hours of the day just sleeping
column3: resting and doing absolutely nothing.  Part of the pride were three adorable cubs
column4: clearly not looking to go to rest any time soon.  While the adults were sleeping
column5: the cute lion cubs had other plans of their own.  I remembered as a child the trouble I got into for making a noise while my parents were trying to take their afternoon nap.  One male lion cub
column6: who clearly had all the courage in the world or couldn’t care less
column7: decided it was time to go and seek some attention from his father
column8: a big male lion sleeping a short distance away from the rest of the pride.  The lion cub carefully approached the King of the Jungle
column9: making us wonder how this whole ordeal was going to turn out.  What happened next totally amazed us.  The lion cub unexpectedly decided to climb on top of his father
column10: curiously investigating his impressive mane.  Still there was not a single response coming from the big male lion.  The lion cub sat on top his father
column11: looking very comfortable
column12: thinking of what else he can do to get his father’s attention.  The cub decided to get down from his father and thought that cuddling with his father would do the trick.  Even after placing his paw on his father’s face
column13: licking him a few times again after
column14: the lion cub realized that he was not going to receive any sort of attention.  The cub turned around and started planning his next move while checking to see what was happening with the rest of the pride members.  At that very moment the big lazy male lion slowly turned onto his back and continued snoozing with his feet up in the air
column15: acting as if nothing happened.  The cub was already so fixated on his new mission that he totally ignored his father and went back to play with the other two cubs.  Even though the male lion did not show any sort of response while his son looked for attention
column16: we were amazed by the unconditional patience and acceptance the male lion showed towards his son.  With a paw the size of the cub’s head
column17: the father could easily have sent his son flying in annoyance which has happened before.  In our opinion this was a sign of true fatherly love as we all knew the big male lion wasn’t really fast asleep all that time and he was well aware of what was going on the whole time. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/lion-cub-adamantly-seeks-attention-220011355.html#9hsrOxinb

column2: I must confess I’m not a great Jew.  Between throwing a literal tantrum every Sunday morning when my dad would forcefully pry me out of bed so that I wouldn’t be late for Hebrew school
column3: and then never returning the temple again after I had a raging Bat Mitzvah
column4: well. . .  I guess you could say my devotion to Judaism is pretty pathetic at best.  Do I fast on Yom Kippur? Of course not—the thought of giving up my morning cup of coffee because I’m “repenting” is simply out of the question.  However
column5: just because you might not find me at the synagogue on a weekly or evenly quarterly basis doesn’t mean that I don’t love being Jewish.  In fact
column6: I look forward to celebrating (and cooking for) most of the holidays
column7: especially Hanukkah. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/hanukkah-game-buffalo-latkes-124300890.html#UrJjVZjJH

Marni Licursi recorded a video that showed a toy Santa ascending a toy ski lift and then sliding down the ski track around her Christmas tree.  The video clocked more than 750
column2: 000 views on TiKTok. Licursi told Storyful that the toy was called Mr Christmas Santa’s Ski Slope
column3: which was purchased by her neighbor in 1992.  She stored the toy in her basement for a few years after her neighbor threw it out
column4: she said.  This year
column5: she decided to test out the 28-year-old decor. “I was thrilled when I discovered all the parts were in the box and it worked! It’s an incredible piece and I have been overwhelmed by all the love I have received from sharing it
column6: ” Licursi told Storyful.  Credit: Marni Licursi via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/vintage-santas-ski-slope-christmas-235537634.html#O0qlqbkny

column1: 2020-12-07 15:40:02#sport#Panda takes first steps into the world#https://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/other/panda-takes-first-steps-into-the-world/vi-BB1bHHOq#https://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/other/panda-takes-first-steps-into-the-world/vi-BB1bHHOq#en#1.0#www.msn.com#"This is little Fan Xing's introduction to the world and he seems quite at home at Ouwehands Zoo in the Netherlands.  Since his birth on May 1 the young giant panda stayed in the maternity pen with his mother Wu Wen.  The 14kg cub sleeps four fours between meals
column2: followed by short and careful walks and long stretching exercises.  Zoologist José Kok says: ""As you could see
column3: this is really the moment that he starts to eat bamboo.  In the beginning
column4: it was only nibbling on it and playing with it
column5: but now you can see that he starts to eat
column6: and we only know if he eats as soon as there are pieces of bamboo in his poo of course
column7: we didn't see that yet
column8: but I think it will happen not far from here. "" Fan Xing's parents went to the Netherlands in 2017 from the panda rescue centre in China.  The bears were supposed to breed because there are not many giant pandas left in the wild.  ""You know
column9: we are very eager to participate in breeding programmes and especially for the giant panda because the giant panda is the symbol for threatened nature.  So right from the beginning
column10: when we started this project
column11: it was our aim to get the pandas here and do the breeding.  Yes
column12: but when the pandas arrived here
column13: mum and dad
column14: they were only three years old.  So we had to wait another three years before they were finally able to mate and get a cub
column15: Kok says.  The young panda's name Fan Xing refers to Van Gogh's painting Starry Night.  Fan comes from Fan Gao
column16: which means Van Gogh in Chinese
column17: while Xing
column18: which means star
column19: and symbolises hope
column20: is also a reference to the panda's father Xing Ya
column21: meaning Elegant Star.  The mother's name Wu Wen means Beautiful Powerful Cloud.  Giant pandas are solitary animals.  The male panda Xing Ya lives in a separate enclosure.  It took a lot of time and creativity to bring the two together to mate.  Kok says: ""We always said we prefer the natural way
column22: and we saw right from the beginning when the female is in oestrus
column23: we had them close to each other.  Normally they live apart
column24: but when she was in distress we would have them a little bit closer to each other
column29: and that was good news because if there was not this mix is good
column30: good feeling between the two of them
column31: you would never have a mating. "" Wu Wen now has at least a few years of rest before another breeding attempt is made.  In the wild
column32: pandas do not often get pregnant
column33: as the bears live solitary lives and females are only fertile for a few days each year.  The Ouwehands zoo in Rhene is the only zoo in the Netherlands where visitors can see giant pandas.  The zoo and the Chinese panda rescue centre made the deal giving the panda's family only a temporary home.  Kok knows the panda's time is limited.  She says: ""Well
column35: he can stay here until he's four years old and then he has to go back to China and really normally the cubs would stay with mum for about two years.  So we have to see how the relationship between these two develops.  And definitely
column36: we're going to get them together again for another mating in the future. "" Wu Wen and Xing Ya will stay in the Netherlands for fifteen years. "#https://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/other/panda-takes-first-steps-into-the-world/vi-BB1bHHOq#gomEg800s

column5: admits UW grad student Melanie Anderson
column6: lead author of the paper describing the Smellicopter
column7: in a university news release.  If
column8: for instance
column9: you had one sensor that could detect toxic particles at a fraction of the concentration of that detectable by another
column10: it would be a no-brainer to use the more sensitive of the two. "#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/tiny-drone-uses-actual-moth-001103394.html#F07w3yEYC

column1: 2020-12-07 12:11:33#sport#‘I thought dogs were slobbery and smelly - until ours brought happiness into our Covid-cramped lives’#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/thought-dogs-were-slobbery-smelly-121133967.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/BLiT.7w9p11UDZz7jlE3zQ--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMjUw/https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/_BxbT9RCoJFXgimpUzQm0w--~B/aD0xNTYzO3c9MjUwMTthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/af0aae6fa95ca6234ad5dd99e0b6fc00#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#The children are late for school and complaining I’ve burned the porridge.  Lockdown stress has made me snappy and I’m on the brink of tears
column2: when suddenly a streak of blond speeds past the kitchen window.  Our Labrador puppy
column3: Herbie
column4: is sprinting round the garden with the two metre long tree-protector tube in his mouth
column5: looking like a triumphant burglar four-legging it from the animal police.  The sight is so silly I laugh
column6: in spite of myself.  I’m reminded once again of the soothing powers of a pet during this pandemic.  Having bought Herbie in March
column7: I am one of two million people in the UK who have become lockdown pet owners; demand for puppies in particular is so great that they have more than doubled in price.  Now
column8: a new book reveals the extent to which pets have brought joy to us during these difficult times: Your Pet
column9: Your Pill
column10: by prominent vet Dr Margit Gabriele Muller
column11: uses elucidating research and statistics to prove what pet owners have long suspected: their furry friends are good for their mental health.  “Pets reduce stress
column12: depression
column13: anxiety and pain
column14: ” explains Dr Muller
column15: 52.  “This is especially true during lockdown when you are living in social isolation. ” Twenty years ago Dr Muller moved from her native Germany to the United Arab Emirates
column16: where she became the state’s first female falcon vet.  She is also an NLP (neuro linguistic programming) coach and proud owner of 23 pets
column17: including five dogs.  “I live alone
column18: they are my family!” she laughs.  Her smiley demeanour is an advert in itself for her thesis.  Yet hers are arguments I would once have scoffed at.  Despite my husband Chris’s protestations otherwise
column19: I long believed that dogs were too smelly and slobbery to be a part of our lives.  But
column20: while research by Battersea Dogs and Cats Home published yesterday suggests nearly a third of new pet owners bought an animal “on impulse”
column21: ours was more of a slow burn.  Three years ago
column22: desperate to leave London
column23: I decided to cut him a deal – if he let us move to the countryside
column24: I would grant him his lifelong ambition of becoming a dog owner.  After that
column25: my attitude shifted.  Partly because rural living made the prospect of a puppy more enticing; partly because our daughter Rosie
column30: were increasingly enamoured by the idea – but mostly because
column31: after leaving the capital in July 2018
column32: the incessant daily reminders that we were due a dog became too irritating to ignore.  When I saw the friend of a friend who breeds puppies looking for a home for Herbie
column34: it felt like a sign.  Chris was about to start working from home
column35: all future plans were scrapped.  If not now
column36: when? The first thing nine-week-old Herbie did on arriving in our house was poop on the carpet.  It quickly became clear
column38: that he injected happiness into our Covid-cramped lives.  I was surprised to discover that even just stroking his tiny body made me feel calmer.  Dr Muller says caressing a dog or other pet provides exactly the same health benefits as skin-on-skin contact with another human.  She cites a study from Australia’s Monash University that found after three minutes of cuddling
column39: levels of oxytocin – the “love” hormone that helps bonding – increase
column40: while a report in the Journal of Psychosomatic Research found five minutes of cuddles increases levels of the well-being and happiness hormones endorphin and dopamine.  “They are the same hormones released as when you’re breastfeeding or cuddling a partner
column41: ” says Dr Muller.  On the rare occasions Herbie wasn’t sleeping during those early weeks
column42: the children built him obstacle courses out of brooms
column43: taught him to “twerk” and humoured his non-stop demands for tummy tickles – their obsession with their new pet so all-consuming they often forgot they were under virtual house arrest. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/thought-dogs-were-slobbery-smelly-121133967.html#aaYAolBdA

column3: Brian James knew that if he used his drone to fly over the spot where the puppy was last seen
column4: he had a chance of finding her. Meadow became lost in the woods in Andes
column5: New York
column6: last month
column7: and her owners
column8: Gary and Debbie Morgan
column9: quickly plastered flyers everywhere and spread the word online.  That's how James learned about the search efforts and decided to get involved.  ""Everybody's got the capability to help
column10: he told World News Tonight.  ""You never know what will come of it. ""James headed to the woods and flew his drone up above the trees
column11: looking closely at the images being captured by the device.  As soon as he saw a patch of white
column12: James zoomed in and saw that it was a dog.  He ran to the area
column13: and was greeted by Meadow
column14: who was uninjured and thrilled to see him after 10 days on her own. Meadow was reunited with the Morgans right before Thanksgiving
column15: and Debbie told World News Tonight her family was ""just so grateful for Brian for showing up when he did and being able to rescue her. "" More stories from theweek. com What Trump is doing isn't politics.  It's something much worse. column2: 9 deer from Japan's Nara Park were found dead with plastic waste in their stomachs
column3: one with 9. 5 pounds of trash.  A Japanese entrepreneur teamed up with a design firm and paper manufacturer to create a new type of bag that's safe for the deer to eat.  These bags are made from recycled milk carton pulp and rice bran.  6 local businesses are using the bags as part of a trial.  Nara Park's deer are believed to be divine messengers and are one of the main tourism attractions in the area.  This video ""Saving Nara's Sacred Deer With Edible 'Plastic' Bags""
column4: first appeared on https://nowthisnews. com/. "#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/saving-naras-sacred-deer-edible-130000083.html#DbxxhSEHC

2020-12-02 22:00:08#sport#Scuba divers find themselves surrounded by curious dolphins#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/scuba-divers-themselves-surrounded-curious-220008482.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/p58LPmnXImUQQMjN3JNlWw--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMTI1/https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/02/5fc810a43b6d0e20a853176d/5fc810a43b6d0e20a853176e_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Scuba diving is a thrilling sport beyond description.  The underwater world is filled with beauty and wonder.  Unusual structures and corals line the bottom of the ocean
column2: creating a landscape that is beautiful beyond description
column3: and the animal life is equally breath taking.  Dolphins are among the most fascinating of all the ocean's creatures.  They are graceful and quick
column4: often appearing for only a moment as they swim past scuba divers.  But occasionally
column5: they are curious enough to venture close to check out the humans that must appear so awkward and clumsy to them.  These divers entered the water in the remote area around Darwin Island in the Galapagos
column6: hoping to see hammerheads and whale sharks
column7: along with any other animals.  They were surprised and thrilled to be surrounded by a large pod of dolphins that were slowly moving through the area.  The playful antics of the dolphins and the inquisitive looks delighted the divers as the pod stayed with them over a minute or two before moving on.  The squeaks and squeals of the dolphins communicating can clearly be heard in this video as the dolphins check them out.  One of the most intelligent creatures on the planet
column8: dolphins are also one of the most loved.  Their faces seem to be set in a permanent smile.  For many
column9: a close up encounter with a dolphin is one of their ultimate dreams.  These lucky scuba divers were fortunate to actually see these beautiful animals in their natural habitat
column10: on their own terms. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/scuba-divers-themselves-surrounded-curious-220008482.html#zMruq36Ge

column1: 2020-12-04 18:02:14#sport#Rescue Crew Uses Steel Barge to Save Giraffes Stranded on Flooded Island in Kenya#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/rescue-crew-uses-steel-barge-180214463.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/04/5fca7a02e75f6906e844bd36/5fca7a06894127000192de07_1920x1080_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Wildlife conservation officials in Kenya are working to save eight giraffes stranded on an island in Lake Baringo by transporting them to a nearby nature preserve on a custom-made steel barge. Footage by Save Giraffes Now (a Texas-based nonprofit that teamed up with Kenya Wildlife Service and the Northern Rangelands Trust to carry out the complicated rescue mission) shows giraffe Asiwa being brought from the flooded island to her new home at a Ruko Community Wildlife Conservancy sanctuary. The animals are part of a group of Rothschild’s giraffes that were sent to the remote Kenyan Rift Valley in 2011 in an effort to save the animals from poachers and to increase the subspecies’ population
column2: People reported. According to reports
column3: the eight giraffes ended up isolated after recent heavy rains turned the peninsula they were living on into an island. Asiwa was the first giraffe to cross the water on the barge
column4: and a second giraffe named Pasaka has since been rescued. “There is great urgency to execute this rescue
column5: ” said David O’Connor
column6: president of Save Giraffes Now.  “We couldn’t have asked for a better result
column7: and we’re eager to move the others soon.  With giraffes undergoing a silent extinction
column8: every one we can protect matters. ” Credit: Tyler Schiffman & Ami Vitale/Save Giraffes Now via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/rescue-crew-uses-steel-barge-180214463.html#2MF6Eqo6W

column1: 2020-12-05 06:46:24#sport#Soldier Surprises Family With Thanksgiving Reunion After Being Separated for Nearly a Year#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/soldier-surprises-family-thanksgiving-reunion-064624444.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/05/5fcb2d5f5068c33bdc2c5d07/5fcb2d61894127000192f7b2_406x720_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#The mother of a US Army combat medic captured her son’s emotional reunion with his two younger sisters on Thanksgiving
column2: after they had been separated for nearly a year due to the coronavirus pandemic. Ashton Delgado last saw his family in December 2019
column3: he told Storyful.  He had moved bases for training but pandemic travel restrictions prevented him from visiting his family in California. “I was finally able to surprise my family on November 23 and have Thanksgiving at home
column4: ” he said.  “It was 325 days of not knowing when COVID was going to allow me to go home
column5: but at last I made it back. ”This footage shows Delgado’s 12 and 13-year-old sisters tearfully embrace him as he turns up unannounced on Thanksgiving. “COVID has not been fun for anybody
column6: and coupled with the ability of not seeing family comes with the struggles of working as a medic in a hospital who sees and treats COVID patients
column7: ” he told Storyful.  “It hasn’t been easy
column8: but finally seeing family has made it worth it. ” Credit: Ashton Young Delgado via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/soldier-surprises-family-thanksgiving-reunion-064624444.html#tCBi2CJNB

column1: 2020-12-03 15:19:34#sport#Where to stay for an amazing beach holiday in South America#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/where-stay-amazing-beach-holiday-151934546.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/yw3.qqipICGKT9T5QRBIZA--~B/aD02MjU7dz0xMDAwO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/3f4f2780f744d16f4dfa05cbccd8ac1a#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#These are unusual times

column2: a single-use-plastic awareness art installation
column3: at this year’s annual Deck the Chairs event at Seawalk Pavilion in Jacksonville Beach. According to Beaches Go Green
