column2: Alberta
column3: on a night this past summer
column4: newly shared video shows. Photographer Siv Heang Tav captured timelapse footage of the comet as it passed over the Elbow River on July 14 while the aurora borealis danced overhead. The meteor – which measures approximately three miles across – was visible to the naked eye from Earth throughout the month of July this year.  It will not be seen again from Earth for approximately 6
column5: 800 years
column6: according to NASA. Speaking to Storyful

column1: 2020-12-04 10:25:44#sport#Postman Makes Special Delivery as Cancer Survivor Gets Van Load of Birthday Cards and Gifts#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/postman-makes-special-delivery-cancer-102544209.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/04/5fca0fe3e61260769200b1f2/5fca0fe5338f380001d977d0_272x480_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"A postman in England had to devote an entire van load to just one lucky customer
column2: when a 10-year-old cancer survivor was inundated with cards and gifts. In footage posted on Facebook
column3: postman Jon Giles can be seen knocking on birthday girl Abbie Paice’s door with two full bags.  He then leads the amazed Abbie to his van
column4: which is packed with boxes of presents and cards. “Normally when I have got my van I deliver to the whole area – about 500 houses
column5: ” Giles tells the young birthday girl in the footage.  “But today I am just coming to your house because my van is full and it’s all for you. ”The 10-year-old
column6: from Chartham
column7: in Kent
column8: has recently marked five years in remission after being first diagnosed with leukemia as a two-year-old
column9: according to Kent Online.  She had been feeling unwell lately
column10: the news site said. “We are just absolutely blown away by the number of cards she got
column11: ” Lisah Paice
column12: the girl’s mother
column13: told Kent Online after issuing a plea for birthday wishes a number of weeks ago on social media. “We never in a million years thought it would reach as far as it did. ”She added
column14: ""We haven’t been able to count them
column15: but we think there are approximately 2
column16: 500 cards and packages. “Our hallway is absolutely filled.  It’s been amazing. ” Credit: Lisah Paice via Storyful"#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/postman-makes-special-delivery-cancer-102544209.html#3K2UYCCN6

column1: 2020-12-04 02:24:16#sport#10 Great Movie Santas
column2: from Kurt Russell to Paul Giamatti (Photos)#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/10-great-movie-santas-kurt-022416223.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/YcP_SMbtSEzn5FHnOCgv1g--~B/aD00MDA7dz02MTg7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en-US/thewrap.com/36d8d8e6de3a8f2283c36ec284026fb1#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#As the embodiment of kindness
column3: generosity
column4: and Yuletide beneficence
column5: Santa Claus presents some mighty big black boots
column6: much less a red suit
column7: for any actor to fill.  But jolly old Saint Nicholas has appeared in the movies for as long as the movies have existed
column8: and here are some of our favorite actors who’ve steered the sleigh (not counting Billy Bob Thornton and anyone else who has played a guy who is pretending to be Santa):Kurt Russell in “The Christmas Chronicles” (2018) and “The Christmas Chronicles 2” (2020): There’s more than a little bit of Russell’s trucker character from “Big Trouble in Little China” in his take on Father Christmas
column9: but that blue-collar bravado and dad-bod energy make this character
column10: in the words of critic Nathan Rabin
column11: “a Santa who f–ks. ”Jim Broadbent
column12: “Arthur Christmas” (2011): In this delightful animated adventure from Aardman
column13: Broadbent plays the current Santa in a long lineage: He assumed the reins from his father (voiced by Bill Nighy)
column14: and is about to pass them along to son Steve (Hugh Laurie)
column15: who has modernized the toy delivery system
column16: reducing Santa to a dotty figurehead.  As voiced by Broadbent
column17: he’s a bit of a dodderer
column18: but still very much in love with the job. Paul Giamatti
column19: “Fred Claus” (2007): Vince Vaughn has the title role of the main man’s ne’er-do-well brother
column20: but this spotty comedy is stolen outright by Giamatti
column21: who displays a level of kindness and joy that he rarely gets to exercise in front of the camera.  The fatsuit and white beard fit the veteran character actor like a fur-trimmed glove. Ed Asner
column22: “Elf” (2003): There’s not an ounce of cynicism or irony to this modern classic.  Asner
column23: whose Lou Grant character once famously growled that he “hate[d] spunk
column24: ” must now rely upon the good will and Christmas spirit of New Yorkers when his sleigh gets stranded in Central Park — thankfully
column25: the actor generates enough holiday cheer to ensure a happy outcome. Tim Allen
column26: “The Santa Clause” (1994): Transforming from a divorced businessman to the Big Red Cheese himself
column27: Allen is funny and relatable as a regular guy who finds himself literally expanding to fit the iconic red suit.  So often in Santa movies
column28: the audience must go on the “oh wow
column29: he’s really real after all” journey
column30: and Allen makes the perfect guide
column31: with his character evolving from cynical to sweet as he completes his metamorphosis into the North Pole’s most famous resident. Douglas Seale
column32: “Ernest Saves Christmas” (1988): Another comedy about the Santa title changing hands features veteran British character actor Seale as a Kringle on the verge of retirement
column33: traveling to Florida to transfer the gig to a kind-hearted kids’ TV host.  For all the wacky slapstick afoot
column35: presenting a Santa who’s both capable of genuine magic while also very much a part of the real world — a tricky balance in any movie
column36: much less one built around Jim Varney’s rubber-faced (and
column39: “Santa Claus: The Movie” (1985): You’d think the guy playing the title role would be the star
column40: but poor Huddleston (“The Big Lebowski”) had to settle for billing beneath Dudley Moore (as an inventive elf) and John Lithgow (devouring the scenery as a corrupt toy magnate).  Still
column41: as overblown (and filled with product placement) as this shrill Christmas epic can be
column42: Huddleston brings genuine warmth to the proceedings
column43: whether he’s a 14th-century woodcutter determined to deliver toys to local children or the man with the bag spanning the globe every December 24. John Call
column44: “Santa Claus Conquers the Martians” (1964): A kiddie adventure so terrible that “Mystery Science Theater 3000
column45: ” Cinematic Titanic and Rifftrax could all goof on it without repeating any jokes
column46: this infamous Christmas turkey nonetheless features Broadway veteran Call (before making this movie
column47: he appeared in the original cast of “Oliver!”) giving us a twinkly-eyed
column48: rosy-cheeked Santa who seems to have stepped out of a Norman Rockwell lithograph.  His “Ho ho ho!” always sounds genuine
column49: even when he’s facing off with antenna-sporting green aliens bearing Wham-O Air Blasters. José Elías Moreno
column50: “Santa Claus” (1959): Unless you grew up watching Mexican television or going to kiddie matinees in the Southwest in the 1960s and early ’70s
column51: you were probably exposed to this trippy import via “Mystery Science Theater 3000. ” And while this film earned the mockery it received from Mike and the bots
column52: it’s one of those bad movies that’s so utterly enthralling that you can’t stop watching it.  Even though this Santa teams up with Merlin to fight the devil (long story)
column53: Moreno gives us a memorable Saint Nick
column54: even when the actor dubbing him into English makes his laugh sound sinister. Edmund Gwenn
column55: “Miracle on 34th Street” (1947): The only actor to win an Oscar for playing Santa Claus
column56: and it’s definitely a case where the Academy got it right.  Gwenn’s Kris Kringle saves the Macy’s parade from a drunken impostor
column57: generates publicity for the department store by alerting customers about better deals being offered by competitors
column58: enchants a young Natalie Wood into believing in magic
column59: and even proves his sanity at a court hearing.  With a performance like this
column60: who wouldn’t believe in Santa? (Honorable mention: Sir Richard Attenborough in the 1994 remake
column61: who’s lovely but can’t hold a candle to the OG. )Read original story 10 Great Movie Santas

2020-12-03 17:36:28#sport#Top Indian teacher wins $1m and gives half away as British nominee named 'Covid hero'#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/top-indian-teacher-wins-1m-173628888.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/BnXHb2H1eRSRKdq3T.XicQ--~B/aD03MTY7dz0xMTQ2O2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/2a1a39564a3bf68df7c0965a711f1fcc#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"A top Indian teacher has pledged to give away half of his $1m prize money after winning an international teaching award
column2: while the British nominee was given a special mention as a 'Covid hero'.  Jamie Frost
column3: a teacher from Tiffin School in Kingston
column4: received a special recognition from the Varkey Foundation Global Teacher Prize for helping young people to learn from home during the Covid-19 crisis.  He won the £34
column5: 000 ""Covid hero"" prize for running a free maths tuition website during the pandemic in a ceremony hosted by Stephen Fry.  Ranjitsinh Disale
column7: who teaches in a village primary school in western Maharashtra state
column8: won the $1m (£750
column9: 000) award for using QR codes and other innovative teaching techniques in his lessons
column10: which were credited with reducing student drop-out rates.  Mr Disale arrived at the school - which is wedged between a cattle shed and a storeroom - in the drought-prone village in 2009.  With few resources
column11: he took on the challenge of specially learning the local language Kannada in order to translate textbooks.  Mr Disale also redesigned the textbooks
column12: embedding them with QR codes to give students access to audio poems
column13: video lectures
column14: stories and to set them homework.  Mr Disale's school was the first in Maharashtra to introduce QR codes
column15: and after he submitted a proposal regarding their efficacy to the state education authorities 2017
column16: the government introduced QR-coded schoolbooks across the province for all grades.  His enthusiasm led to the 100 per cent attendance of girls in classrooms
column17: in an area where girls commonly drop out of school after getting married.  He also provides online science lessons to students in 83 countries and oversees an international project building associations between young people living in conflict zones.  Mr Disale’s decision to share half his prize money with the remaining nine teacher finalists will mean over £41
column18: 000 will be given to educators from Brazil
column19: Italy
column20: Malaysia
column21: Nigeria
column22: South Africa

column1: 2020-12-03 17:02:03#sport#Oreo Is Doing This for the First Time Ever#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/oreo-doing-first-time-ever-170203520.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/TrAePhwOpEOr3KNF7nJ9Cw--~B/aD04Nzk7dz0xMjAwO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/https://media.zenfs.com/en/galvanized/ebbfd444f4e35cb25ab34beb5709fade#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"Oreo is hopping aboard the celebrity partnership train with its first-ever collaboration on a music-inspired cookie.  The cookie maker has partnered with none other than Lady Gaga to bring you limited-edition Chromatica Oreos.  Featuring a pink wafer shell stuffed with bright green creme
column2: this cookie is unlike anything you've ever seen Oreo do before. The pink and green Oreos are named after the Grammy Award–winning artist's sixth studio album Chromatica
column3: which was released in May of this year.  Besides the colorful update
column4: the cookies will also be etched with brand-new designs reminiscent of the album's cover art—all in the service of transporting fans to ""the world of Chromatica
column5: where kindness rules all things
column6: according to Gaga herself.  (Related: McDonald's Is Making These 8 Major Upgrades. )⚔️ LADY GAGA x @OREO x Chromatica 💓 Dropping soon! pic. twitter. com/Gtd5qeZXZi— Lady Gaga (@ladygaga) December 2
column7: 2020""Together with Lady Gaga
column8: we cannot wait to unleash her world of Chromatica on our Oreo cookie and encourage fans to spread musical messages of kindness to create a brighter and more connected country
column9: Justin Parnell
column10: senior director of Oreo
column11: said in a press release. The limited-edition release will be followed up with a ""Sing It With Oreo"" campaign
column12: which encourages fans to send musical messages to loved ones for a chance to win an assortment of Lady Gaga swag and experiences. Six-packs of the cookies will drop in January everywhere where Oreos are sold
column13: and they'll be around while supplies last (which may not be long at all).  A release date for full-size packs hasn't yet been announced—but worry not.  You can sign up for the Lady Gaga x Oreo Stan Club to get notified as soon as they drop.  Plus
column14: the first 1
column15: 000 people to sign up will get a complimentary cookie pack when they're released. Don't forget to sign up for our newsletter to get the latest grocery news delivered straight to your inbox. "#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/oreo-doing-first-time-ever-170203520.html#OEGpIqsbl

2020-12-03 16:00:36#sport#Puppy love between baby and his dog is super sweet#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/puppy-love-between-baby-dog-160036619.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/m6cRv4n5kjR7pnJRfjttSA--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMTI1/https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/03/5fc90daf5068c33bdc2c523a/5fc90daf5068c33bdc2c523b_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"There is no love stronger than a boy and his dog.  Following you will see this deep connection between 18 month old Harvey and his dog
column2: Bella.  Bella is a 5 year old Terrier mix pup from Surrey British Columbia
column3: Canada.  Bella has great parents that up until a years and half ago she was the main ""child"" in the home.  Bella was very use to receiving all the attention until her little ""brother"" Harvey came along.  Bella has always been an extremely friendly and lovable pup.  She has always been able to get along with anyone
column4: and any other dogs
column5: making it great for taking her along on vacation and to even just the local dog parks.  Now that Harvey is very mobile
column6: he is also building an extremely lovable personality.  His love doesn’t only include his parents
column7: with hugs and kisses daily
column8: Harvey also loves his dog.  Here you will see just how much love Harvey has for Bella.  Yes most kids love animals and pets
column9: but Harvey goes and shows to the extreme.  Climbing into bed with Bella on her favourite dog bed is only one place that she gets cuddles from her brother .  Whether on the couch curled in a ball
column10: trying to sleep
column11: Harvey will always snuggle up to Bella to comfort her and show his love.  Rolling around on the dog bed
column12: snuggling and hugging Bella
column13: Harvey at times gets a little “heavy “ on this little pooch and she will escape his grappling for a quieter location.  Harvey always finds Bella
column14: he loves her to bits.  As you can see there is nothing more special than the love of a young child and his dog.  What a beautiful relationship these two have
column15: true love. "#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/puppy-love-between-baby-dog-160036619.html#ENKxhDW5b

column7: ” Radoslaw Ratajszczak
column8: the head of Zoo Wroclow
column9: told Reuters.  Chevrotains are facing extinction due to hunting and to palm oil plantations in their native home. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/rare-mouse-deer-born-camera-173153398.html#GgqVnPMSH

2020-12-01 18:32:49#sport#'Magical Morning': Moose Calf Nuzzles Mother as Snow Falls in Alaska Yard#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/magical-morning-moose-calf-nuzzles-183249121.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-12/01/5fc68c5b0da63868dc33dde2/5fc68c6489412700019244d5_1920x1080_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#A family in Homer
column2: Alaska
column3: were surprised by a tender scene in their yard on Sunday
column4: November 29
column5: as a mother moose resting on the ground was nuzzled by her calf amid falling snow. Jennifer Gibson captured footage of the mesmerizing moment from her living room.  Her seven-year-old son can be heard talking briefly before he’s hushed by Gibson and her husband for fear they may be disturbing the moose family’s “private moment. ”Speaking to Storyful
column6: Gibson said
column7: “It was early in the morning
column8: before the sun was up
column9: and my family and I were having a quiet Sunday morning when we noticed the moose outside in our yard. ”After spotting the animals
column10: the family watched for approximately a “half-hour” through their living room window as the pair ate grass and played in their front yard.  Later in the morning
column11: two more moose showed up on their property and the mother chased them away
column12: according to Gibson. She added
column13: “I took many pictures and videos of these moose … It was a magical morning for us and a rare event to see the moose so up close and personal. ” Credit: Jennifer Gibson via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/magical-morning-moose-calf-nuzzles-183249121.html#7jGUmv8rN

column12: Argentina From Paraguay through the Pampa to Patagonia
column13: rural culture revolves around the horse.  Playing gaucho is one way to immerse yourself; another is polo
column14: a quintessential Argentine pastime.  You’ll find opportunities for both at traditional country estancias (cattle ranches) such as Los Potreros in the Sierra Chicas south of Córdoba.  Or try a two-hour polo taster on the outskirts of Buenos Aires at the grand mock-Tudor Estancia Villa Maria.  A seven-night package at Estancia Los Potreros (00 54 911 5900 6468; estancialospotreros. com) costs from £2

column1: 2020-11-30 13:26:15#sport#How Taiwan uses Buddhist literature for environmental education#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/taiwan-uses-buddhist-literature-environmental-132615512.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/PhLAWl605OmH0d4xbH7sqw--~B/aD05NDA7dz0xNDQwO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/https://media.zenfs.com/en/the_conversation_us_articles_815/110bf867c7fc499ddb59dca03ab02111#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Climate change is one of the biggest challenges that the world faces.  A United Nations report has cautioned that greenhouse gas emissions due to human activity are at a record high
column2: “with no signs of slowing down. ” Many nations are recording weather extremes
column3: higher average temperatures and rising seas.  Meanwhile
column4: the first wave of increasing numbers of climate refugees points to how a changing environment will reshape human life.  The changes in climate may have been caused by previous and current generations of adults
column5: but it is the future generations that will have to deal with its worst effects.  Today’s children will play a critical role in protecting the environment.  Confronting the crisis will require much change – and education is an urgent first step. As experts have said
column6: this education will need to start early
column7: so that environmentally friendly practices become habits at a young age.  Taiwan offers an example of how to teach children about caring for their environment.  Environmental attitudes in TaiwanBy the early 1990s
column8: rapid economic development had led to environmental degradation in Taiwan
column9: an island in the China Sea and home to nearly 24 million people.  The air quality in the cities was hazardous
column10: a third of rivers were polluted and garbage often didn’t make it to landfills.  Today
column11: however
column12: the Taiwanese take pride in their island’s natural beauty – from coastal wetlands to lush green mountains – and in their success in protecting the environment.  Taiwan is especially known for its high rates of recycling and elaborate sorting systems that even include a category for food waste destined for pig slop.  According to self-reported figures
column13: Taiwan now recycles 20% more than the U. S.  – and any visitor can attest to the seriousness of recycling efforts. As a scholar of Chinese Buddhism
column14: I have been looking at how religious groups address contemporary issues
column15: including environmentalism
column16: in children’s literature.  Teaching childrenIn Taiwan
column17: over a third of adults identify themselves as Buddhist
column18: more than any other religion
column19: making it a significant cultural force.  Buddhist groups have been at the forefront of efforts to care for the environment.  Included in their effort is Buddhist literature for children that reflects environmental concerns.  Picture books on this topic take two approaches: In one
column20: bodhisattvas – wise and powerful supernatural beings that can appear in the world to help human beings – serve as models for children in the way that they protect the environment. For example
column21: in the book
column22: “Samantabhadra Bodhisattva’s Great Battle against the Trash Monster
column23: ” published by the Buddhist organization Dharma Drum Mountain
column24: the first page of the story introduces a bodhisattva who wants to transform the polluted world into one that is pure. This bodhisattva meets a young boy who says he has nightmares about a monster made out of trash.  As it turns out
column25: the monster has been appearing because the boy’s room is a messy mountain of garbage.  When he cleans it up
column26: the bodhisattva prompts him to properly sort everything he throws away
column27: reflecting real practices.  Then the little boy decides to become a “little pioneer of world environmentalism
column28: ” and accompanies the bodhisattva in cleaning up parks and beaches.  In this story
column29: the little boy’s concerns grow from his own room to the bigger world
column30: with the bodhisattva modeling compassionate action.  Historically
column31: bodhisattvas have been invoked to help people in times of extreme need (such as a storm at sea)
column32: and intervening for the good of the environment updates their role for contemporary times. In this case Buddhism is central to the story
column33: and cleaning polluted spaces becomes a metaphor for spiritual purification.  The reader looks to a bodhisattva or Buddha as guide
column34: and is inspired to take action.  Caring for the environmentBut in other cases
column35: Buddhist organizations do not use figures like bodhisattvas to teach about environmentalism.  The stories do not feature bodhisattvas as characters
column36: and the narratives may not be obviously Buddhist
column37: but offer environmental education in the context of a broader Buddhist education.  Being a well-rounded Buddhist
column39: means knowing and respecting the environment. They may use stories about plants and animals to teach children about such things as the life cycle of coal and symbiotic relationships between animals
column40: like that of rhinoceroses and oxpeckers
column41: which are popularly thought to eat ticks and other insects
column42: though the reality is more complex. Children learn about biology and how living beings are interconnected.  This lends itself to thinking holistically about the environment
column43: and these stories often prompt children to look at the world from the perspective of other living beings.  Published by a major Buddhist organization
column44: the book “Record of the Wanderings of a Plastic Bag” goes a step farther in presenting other perspectives. A plastic bag starts out as plaything for a baby
column45: then becomes a place for the cat to nap.  The family’s grandfather claims it to collect tomatoes
column47: he washes the bag and hangs it to dry.  A bit later
column48: he uses it to carry worn-out shoes to be repaired
column49: at which point the bag blows away.  It travels joyfully on the wind accompanied by a leaf and a candy wrapper
column50: but is eventually swept up into a garbage bag.  A dog rips open the garbage
column51: and the bag blows away again
column52: only to be picked up by a child with a stick who treats it as a toy.  After it is abandoned by the child – very sadly for the bag – it is picked up
column53: recycled and transformed into shopping bag.  This is a happy ending
column54: reflected by the bag’s happy smile. The author
column56: writes that she used the bag as a character in the hope of stimulating children’s compassion
column57: leading them to cherish the objects that they use.  “Cherishing
column59: leads to a deeper understanding of environmentalism.  There is connection between being able to take the perspective of a plastic bag –entailing both intellectual and emotional responses – and valuing that object
column60: which otherwise might be seen as a piece of trash. Young readers are prompted to take the perspective of these nonhuman characters
column61: changing how they think about the world and their own actions.  This connects to the Buddhist teachings of karma and reincarnation
column62: which mean that every intentional action has a consequence.  Equally important
column63: although one couldn’t be reborn as a plastic bag
column64: one could be reborn as an insect or endangered animal.  On another level
column65: taking the perspective of a plastic bag helps readers to understand how all elements of the universe are interconnected
column66: a teaching that takes its most sophisticated philosophical form in Huayan Buddhism.  Impact of children’s literatureBy showing children that they have responsibility in caring for the environment
column67: these books work to produce what sociologist Bengt Larsson has called
column69: “ecological selves. ”Although studies on the long-term effects of children’s literature are limited
column70: there’s some evidence that this approach is effective in fostering concern and care for environmental issues.  [Deep knowledge
column71: daily.  Sign up for The Conversation’s newsletter. ]For example
column72: a study in Australia found that anthropomorphism
column73: which attributes human traits to animals and things
column74: increased children’s concern for parts of the environment
column75: as did their emotional investment in the stories.  That is
column76: certain types of books do seem to change children’s attitudes.  As I found in my research
column77: this is something Buddhist organizations recognize as well and incorporate into their educational mission.  Growing up Buddhist means growing into environmentalism and global citizenship. This article is republished from The Conversation
column78: a nonprofit news site dedicated to sharing ideas from academic experts.  It was written by: Natasha Heller
column79: University of Virginia. Read more: * Victoria just gave 2 billion litres of water back to Indigenous people.  Here’s what that means for the rest of Australia * Are we recycling too much of our trash?Natasha Heller does not work for
column81: own shares in or receive funding from any company or organization that would benefit from this article
column82: and has disclosed no relevant affiliations beyond their academic appointment. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/taiwan-uses-buddhist-literature-environmental-132615512.html#MEEfIyGHJ

column2: you can feed stray animals by recycling#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/kyiv-feed-stray-animals-recycling-133553235.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-11/24/5fbd0ce55068c36eeb1eab47/5fbd0ce55068c36eeb1eab48_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"A Ukrainian entrepreneur has come up with a unique way of feeding stray cats and dogs. . .  by using recycled plastic bottles as currency to buy them food.  Installed in one of Kyiv's residential areas at the end of October
column3: the reimagined vending machine has collected almost 320
column4: 000 pounds of recyclables within the first two weeks
column5: according to the project founder Rufat Raimov.  “A lot of people come here
column6: but mainly over the weekends after they collect plastic bottles during the weekdays.  You can see it yourself that families come here during the weekends.  Parents give a bag to kids and kids puts bottles into a machine one by one.  Over the weekends
column7: machine attracts a lot of people.  In a workday
column8: we collect 2-3 bags of bottles while over the weekend day we collect at least six bags. "" He’s proud that the initiative helps to tackle two problems in the capital - recycling plastic waste and nourishing stray animals.  One plastic bottle equals 20 grams of food dispersed by the machine onto a pet bowl.  Another bowl placed near can also be filled with water by any customer.  ""We have regular customers.  They tell us: ""It is our ritual. "" A kid collects bottles and then comes up to parents saying: ""Let's go and feed animals. "" To raise a socially responsible generation is our main advantage. "" Raimov has already teamed up with a Ukrainian charity for the initiative and hopes to expand the project by installing more machines in Ukraine - as well as new ones placed indoors. "#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/kyiv-feed-stray-animals-recycling-133553235.html#4EfNVaW0t

column4: moments after she placed it outside
column5: it caught the attention of the chipmunk. In the following days
column6: Hansberger continued to put out fruits and vegetables for Thelonious
column7: who kept coming back for more. Hansberger then got creative
column8: dressing up the table with different themes that Thelonious appeared eager to examine. This video shows Thelonious enjoying what Hansberger described as a “festive lunch in a colorful wonderland
column9: ” while surrounded by tiny artificial Christmas trees. While Hansberger hopes her efforts bring Thelonious a little happiness every day
column10: she said his visits are doing the same for her. “He has given me a lot of joy and eased a lot of anxiety about the pandemic
column11: loss of work
column12: and the wild election
column13: ” Hansberger told Storyful.  Credit: Angela Hansberger via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/chipmunk-chomps-festive-lunch-served-174458818.html#ZAolo16tK

column1: 2020-11-29 09:19:43#sport#Georgia Kid Executes Neat Basketball Skills on Treadmill#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/georgia-kid-executes-neat-basketball-091943499.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-11/29/5fc3686d3b6d0e62847042c5/5fc368700721110001ad7a3f_1920x1080_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Zeke Vozniak
column2: a sports-obsessed seven-year-old boy from Georgia
column3: is always looking for new ways to demonstrate his basketball skills
column4: so when he saw a treadmill in his great-grandmother’s garage
column5: a new idea sprang to mind. In footage shared on November 25 by his mother
column6: Jaclyn Vozniak
column7: Zeke dribbles two basketballs while walking backwards on the treadmill
column8: ably dribbling the ball through his legs while also executing 360-degree turns. Jaclyn explained to Storyful
column9: “When he walked into his great-grandmother’s garage he noticed a treadmill.  He was ecstatic since he hasn’t had any treadmill access since the coronavirus started and he missed dribbling on it. ”Unfortunately
column10: he didn’t have any basketballs. “So
column11: Zeke’s dad went to Walmart and purchased two basketballs
column12: ” Vosniak added. After filming the video
column13: both basketballs were left at his 93-year-old grandmother’s home in North
column14: Augusta
column15: where he can use them in future for more unorthodox basketball drills.  Credit: Jaclyn Vozniak via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/georgia-kid-executes-neat-basketball-091943499.html#hbFfdldcK

column1: 2020-11-27 18:31:45#sport#Migrating Stingrays Near Alabama's Gulf State Pier Captured on Drone Footage#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/migrating-stingrays-near-alabamas-gulf-183145192.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-11/27/5fc14744e61260517927d9a8/5fc147460721110001ad579c_1280x720_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#A large school of stingrays was spotted near Gulf Shores
column2: Alabama
column3: video filmed in September and shared on Tuesday
column4: November 24
column5: shows. Drone pilot Travis Middleton captured footage of cownose rays swimming amongst several sharks near a pier that recently experienced weather damage. Speaking to Storyful
column6: Middleton said he was flying his drone along the Gulf Coast to record the aftermath of the Hurricane Sally when he saw the rays
column7: swimming near the Gulf State Park Pier on September 30. “I had heard about the migration in the past and always wanted to capture it but had no idea it would be happening when I was shooting that day
column8: ” he said. He added
column9: “For the first time flying my drone I felt a little nervous just because it was such an overwhelming thing to see.  It was truly one of the more beautiful things I have had the chance to capture. ”Although stingray sightings are common near Alabama’s shores.  Middleton wrote on Twitter that he never witnessed a stingray migration before seeing it on the “screen” of his drone remote. Cownose rays can be found along the Gulf of Mexico.  Changes to their migration patterns can often be triggered by seasonal changes to water temperature and sun orientation

column1: 2020-11-29 13:00:09#sport#Crystal clear waters of Canada's Great Lakes hold mysterious shipwrecks#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/crystal-clear-waters-canadas-great-130009120.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/oFjnOwNrqwY8l8PIW.yweg--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMTI1/https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-11/29/5fc39db3f1b75b4b7362d169/5fc39db3f1b75b4b7362d16a_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Tobermory is a small harbour tucked into the shore of Lake Huron's massive and beautiful Georgian Bay.  Mare than 20 historic shipwrecks from a long ago time lay on the bottom
column2: inviting adventurous scuba divers to venture beneath the waves to explore them.  Wooden steamships with massive boilers that propelled them over the lakes with their cargo were once commonly used to deliver food
column3: building materials
column4: and other products between cities and even between Canada and the United States of America.  The five Great Lakes are among the largest bodies of fresh water in the world
column5: created during the ice age when glaciers carved paths and left rivers and lakes behind when they melted.  Lake Huron is situated on the Canada/U. S.  border and it's northern shore is Georgian Bay
column6: almost as large as the rest of the lake itself.  The tiny
column7: but picturesque town of Tobermory is a popular place to visit
column8: especially for those who seek an opportunity to scuba dive in cold
column9: but crystal clear conditions.  The visibility is a blessing because there is a lot to see near Tobermory.  This is where marine Fathom Five National Marine Park is located.  Famous for the Flowerpot Island with it's unique structures towering high above the shore
column10: land adventurers also flock to the area for sightseeing and pictures.  The 420 million year old dolomite has been worn by the weather and waves to create mysterious caves and structures both above and beneath the water.  But Fathom Five holds the allure that brings scuba divers from around the world to visit more than 20 old wrecks that have been surprisingly well preserved in the icy depths.  Wooden beams
column11: rudders
column12: boilers and ship hardware are on the lake's bottom
column13: just as they were when the wrecks came to rest after their destruction.  A few of the wrecks have actually been placed intentionally to create interesting dive sites for exploration.  Such is the case with this ship
column14: the Caroline Rose which was built in the 1940s in Nova Scotia
column15: Canada.  Originally sunk by mishap
column16: it was towed to its current location to make it accessible for scuba enthusiasts.  A trip to Tobermory holds something for everyone.  Summer scuba diving events are held by Float n' Flag Dive Centre in Burlington for those looking to investigate this area and the wonders it holds. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/crystal-clear-waters-canadas-great-130009120.html#UPzpHlP9z

The commotion woke Alejandra who grabbed her camera and captured the heartwarmingly hilarious moment on film.  Alejandra
column2: a chef

2020-11-24 09:44:54#sport#Five of the best herbs to grow in winter#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/five-best-herbs-grow-winter-094454309.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/ivGKKJ79tO9ezn2VWVb0Lg--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMjUw/https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/zpjRKgIRUaZAh5gdAHAl5Q--~B/aD0xMzMxO3c9MjEyOTthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/398523413d5c13b8eddcb10acaf6ee3f#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"I've put my pots of tender salvias and succulents away under cover
column2: and replaced them on the terrace table with a collection of my favourite culinary herbs.  I've also just bought a nice wirework set of shelves from antique shop Branching Out that I'll stock with potted herbs
column3: so I don't spend winter evenings playing hide and seek in the garden.  We all know and love evergreen bay
column4: rosemary
column5: thyme and sage
column6: but there are other herbs that will sit out the winter's cold and bring cheer and flavour.  So ring the changes and sing the praises of myrtle
column7: hyssop and winter savoury.  There's a whole world of hearty flavours in the herb garden.  We just need the time and confidence to try them.  Myrtle With warmer winters
column8: myrtle (Myrtus communis) should be planted more frequently.  Its small baylike leaves smell lovely
column9: so pot it in well-drained gritty compost
column10: and place by the front door to enjoy each time you pass.  With small fragrant cream flowers full of furry golden stamens
column11: pinkish stems and pretty blue/black berries
column12: it's a plant for all seasons.  Herb expert Jekka McVicar tells me it's one of her favourite herbs: ""I harvest myrtle berries in November to make myrtle
column13: rather than sloe gin.  It has a warm spicy flavour
column14: ideal for Christmas.  The leaves can be used in stews and soups
column15: are especially good with pork and game
column16: and would be excellent in pork sausages
column17: she says.  Keep myrtle cosy under the eaves of your house
column18: wrapped in fleece if the temperatures really plummet and away from bitter wind and wet.  The variety 'Tarentina' is more compact
column19: and 'Variegata' has silvery leaves that look good with the pink-tinged creamy flowers.  Hyssop Hyssop (Hyssopus officinalis) is a dense hardy perennial and member of the mint family
column20: native of the sunny Mediterranean.  In tiny quantities it's delicious with fish
column21: meat and vegetables.  A holy herb
column22: traditionally it was hung in homes to protect from the evil eye
column23: and was used to flavour absinthe.  Tisanes made with the leaves and sweetened with honey will soothe a seasonal sore throat.  With bright blue flower spikes
column24: it looks good edging the beds of the herb garden. "#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/five-best-herbs-grow-winter-094454309.html#8r2XWCvcu

column1: 2020-11-26 13:02:18#sport#How to make sherry-baked pears stuffed with chocolate and marzipan#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/sherry-baked-pears-stuffed-chocolate-130218368.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/W5tbi5R8tvag1KHqA.tIEg--~B/aD0xMDE1O3c9MTYyNDthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/e02dc621820274469eeb9d1dc98a6f2c#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#When winter comes around
column2: it can be a challenge for pastry chefs to come up with yet more creative ways to make a pear sing.  Pear sorbet
column3: pear crumble
column4: poached pears
column5: pear trifle
column6: pear tart… the list goes on.  A few years ago
column7: when I took on private chef jobs on my days off from Llewelyn’s restaurant in south London
column8: I came across a chef who stuffed pears full of amaretti biscuits
column9: sloshed over some sherry and baked them.  They were so unbelievably delicious.  I thought about those pears a lot and would make iterations of them at all the restaurants I worked at during pear season.  The version I’m sharing today has added chopped chocolate and diced marzipan.  And even though I’m not normally a sherry fan
column10: using it here with the pears works wonderfully.  I made these recently for some friends who claimed to dislike both sherry and marzipan
column11: and they were instantly won over.  I hope you will be
column12: too.  Chocolate and sherry baked pears These pears
column13: while being very low effort and quick to assemble
column14: are full of flavour and really moreish.  Perfect on their own or with ice cream.  Don’t let the marzipan throw you off; it bakes and becomes crispy and delivers loads of flavour. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/sherry-baked-pears-stuffed-chocolate-130218368.html#LTHjH4Vqv

column1: 2020-11-27 19:56:05#sport#Woman Raises Funds for Elderly Veteran Who Took Delivery Job to Fix Roof#https://news.yahoo.com/woman-raises-funds-elderly-veteran-195605027.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-11/27/5fc15a623b6d0e6284703f5c/5fc15a623b6d0e6284703f5d_o_U_v2.png#en#1.0#news.yahoo.com#A Utah woman used social media to raise money for an elderly veteran who took a delivery job to help pay for repairs to his home. Jen Cantwell Weiss from Ogden shared footage on November 15 showing a delivery driver struggling to get up the steps of her home as he dropped off groceries.  “I didn’t watch this video til after he was already gone
column2: or else I would have gone out to help him
column3: ” she wrote on Facebook.  A relative of the man saw the footage and put him in touch with Weiss. Weiss discovered the man
column4: named Larry
column5: is a veteran who suffered a stroke earlier in 2020 and had to relearn how to walk.  Weiss shared his story on Facebook
column6: saying he took the delivery job to pay for repairs to his roof
column7: and appealed for people to help him with the costs. Weiss posted his Venmo information and the donations started to roll in
column8: she said.  “I have been in touch with him and he is overwhelmed with gratitude
column9: ” she wrote on Facebook.  “He did NOT ask for any help
column10: but I love that people are touched by his story and want to help lighten his load a bit. ”Larry told local media that the donations covered his roof repairs and he no longer had to do deliveries. Weiss shared an update on Facebook
column11: saying Larry and his wife “requested that rather than continuing to donate to him
column12: you donate to Toys for Tots or your local food bank.  He says he has received more than enough and feels there are so many others out there who need the help more than he does. ”“He expresses his heartfelt gratitude for everything people have sent
column13: ” Weiss wrote.  Credit: Jen Cantwell Weiss via Storyful#https://news.yahoo.com/woman-raises-funds-elderly-veteran-195605027.html#S23wmezM4

column1: 2020-11-27 06:00:15#sport#Jamie Oliver Turns Leftover Mashed Potatoes Into a Brilliant Cheese Pie#https://finance.yahoo.com/news/jamie-oliver-turns-leftover-mashed-060015576.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/KiJvz_x_Sy9wt9rUMM.WqA--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xNTAw/https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/MfTebP1jpAwHMoLbx9MlmQ--~B/aD0xNjUwO3c9MjIwMDthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en/bloomberg_markets_842/e3f8e11d2837fdfa8424d20a4d2d1b83#en#1.0#finance.yahoo.com#(Bloomberg) -- Editor’s Note: As more people are working from home
column2: Bloomberg Pursuits is running a weekly Lunch Break column that highlights a notable recipe from a favorite cookbook and the hack that makes it genius.  This holiday season
column3: let’s gives thanks for mashed potatoes.  They are the MVPs of the industry
column4: a mainstay of weekday dinners
column5: and the anchor  of so many festive dinners.  According to Google Trends data
column6: they have been
column7: unsurprisingly
column8: the most popular side dish for American Thanksgiving. Mashed potatoes are
column9: however
column10: invariably a supporting player behind more muscular turkeys
column11: prime ribs
column12: roast chicken
column13: and anything that might come with a bowl of gravy.  Jamie Oliver invites you to rethink the possibilities. The ever-popular British cook catapulted to international prominence as the Naked Chef in the late ’90s.   Now
column14: he might be known as the Data Chef.  In his new cookbook
column15: 7 Ways: Easy Ideas for Every Day of the Week (Flatiron Books; $35)
column16: Oliver worked with major supermarkets across the U. K.  to determine the ingredients consumers buy most. “My dream was to try and write the most accessible cookbook I’ve ever written
column17: ” says Oliver via a phone interview.  What that means
column18: he adds
column19: is considering what people have on hand
column20: as well as cost
column21: variety
column22: and of course
column23: flavor.  “I used data to drive this creation.  It’s not glamorous
column24: and I don’t typically like it
column25: but it’s fascinating.  We were churning through thousands of items at major supermarkets.  I wanted to study food that most of us buy every week. ”From his research
column26: Oliver determined 30 of the most popular foods purchased at supermarkets.  He then selected 18 to feature in his book—seven different ways
column27: per the title—with the goal of staving off boredom for home cooks whose supermarket habits are on repeat.  They’re all obvious and accessible: salmon
column34: and a pepper-crusted number with whisky sauce. Likewise
column35: Oliver’s potato chapter ranges from Indian-accented baked potatoes to a potato “lasagna” (aka gratin) made by layering slices in a creamy cheese sauce.  Most compelling is his savory pie with a mashed potato “crust. ”“I pair spring onions and tomatoes with oozy cheese to create the perfect flavor contrast with the soft
column36: creamy mash—which also has a pleasingly crispy outer edge
column38: the dish radiates comfort.  Oliver calls for two kinds of cheddar in his dish
column39: but it’s wide open to interpretation.  “Feel free to mix up the cheese
column40: based on what you’ve got. ” The most important part is the golden potato crust.  While mashed potatoes feature as a topping for such classics as shepherd’s pie and moussaka
column41: it’s not so common to find them working as the bottom layer
column42: too.  Though it’s firm enough to cut into slices
column43: the pie could double as a dressed-up casserole.  You could just spoon it onto plates in one gorgeous pile.  The tomatoes add a refreshing bite but they’re not necessary.  Hot sauce makes a great addition
column44: if you’re so inclined. Even as everyone is scaling down this year’s Thanksgiving feast
column45: it’s hard not to overestimate how much mashed potatoes you’ll want.  Leftovers are inevitable—and now
column46: very welcome.  “This one is perfect if you’ve made a bumper batch of mash
column48: and then shouts: “Happy holidays!” The following recipe is adapted from 7 Ways: Easy Ideas for Every Day of the Week
column49: by Jamie Oliver. Testers Note: This recipe works best with drier mashed potatoes
column50: ones made without excessive milk and butter.  Of course
column51: that’s not what most people want for Thanksgiving.  If you have extra creamy mashed potatoes
column52: cook them down so they’re as dense as possible.  Mash in an additional boiled potato or two
column53: if you have them.  If you have less mashed potato
column54: you can make this pie in a smaller baking dish
column55: with less filling.  It’s supremely adaptable. Crispy Cheesy Mashed Potato Pie Serves 4 to 63 lb.  Yukon gold potatoes; if using leftover mashed potatoes
column56: you’ll need about 6 cups2/3 lb.  ripe tomatoes (optional)1 large bunch of scallions
column59: coarsely gratedSalt and freshly ground pepper4 tbsp.  unsalted butter
column60: or to tasteExtra virgin olive oil
column62: for serving (optional)Peel the potatoes and chop into even-sized chunks.  Cook in a large pan of boiling salted water until tender
column67: and dice the flesh.  Toss with a good pinch of sea salt and transfer to a sieve to drain.  Press out any excess liquid from the tomatoes and mix with the scallions and cheese.  Check for seasoning. Preheat the oven to 400F.  Drain the potatoes
column68: then mash really well with the butter and season to perfection.  Once cool enough to handle
column69: use oiled hands to flatten a little more than half the mashed potatoes in the bottom and a bit up the sides of a 12- by 8-inch nonstick baking pan.  Spread the tomato-cheese mixture over the bottom
column70: almost to the edges.  Press the remaining mashed potatoes on top
column71: smoothing it out and covering the filling.  Make a pattern
column72: if you like on the edge.  Brush the top of the pie with olive oil and bake for about 40 minutes
column73: or until golden and crisp.  Let cool slightly
column74: then slice.  Serve with hot sauce
column75: if desired.  For more articles like this
column76: please visit us at bloomberg. comSubscribe now to stay ahead with the most trusted business news source. ©2020 Bloomberg L. P. #https://finance.yahoo.com/news/jamie-oliver-turns-leftover-mashed-060015576.html#VL4PNmhQl

column1: 2020-11-26 17:41:59#sport#Soldier Surprises Parents for Thanksgiving After Three Years Apart#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/solider-surprises-parents-thanksgiving-three-174159449.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-11/26/5fbfea0563753c5ff52b456a/5fbfea08338f380001d84d18_202x360_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#A mother and father in New York received a very special Thanksgiving surprise when their son returned home for the holiday on November 25. column2: Deury
column3: surprising his parents in their Harlem apartment on the eve of Thanksgiving.  He said his brother was stationed in Japan for three years and had not seen his mother during that time. In the footage
column4: Dariel Disla can be seen calling his mother and father to wait in the living room
column5: reassuring them that “nothing bad” is happening.  He said he sneezed to give his brother the signal to enter. “This was a Thanksgiving surprise as we entered the house hours before Thanksgiving day
column6: ” Dariel said.  “My parents were in shock.  My mother cried as she was filled with joy. ” Credit: Dariel Disla via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/solider-surprises-parents-thanksgiving-three-174159449.html#ksSxDwYen

column1: 2020-11-24 10:14:48#sport#Toddler Leads Pony Around Farmyard in Toy Land Rover#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/toddler-leads-pony-around-farmyard-101448797.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-11/24/5fbcde0106c4ef4529dc51a7/5fbcde08338f380001d7d659_1920x1080_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#A toddler from Shropshire has proved you’re never too young to help in a stable yard
column2: leading a pony out to pasture in her miniature off-road vehicle. Footage of 11-month-old Daisy and her pony
column3: Minnie
column4: was captured by mum Nicky Golsteyn
column5: who shared the footage on the Rowton Stables Facebook page on November 17. Speaking to Storyful
column6: Golsteyn was keen to point out that the young equine enthusiast wasn’t in danger at any point. “A few people have asked if it was dangerous as it looks like the pony is tied to the Land Rover.  But her lead rope was actually only looped through the little step of the Land Rover
column7: so if she did decide to wander off she wouldn’t have taken Daisy and the Land Rover with her
column8: ” Golsteyn said. She added
column9: “Minnie just loves following Daisy anywhere. ” Credit: Nicky Golsteyn via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/toddler-leads-pony-around-farmyard-101448797.html#rYz9W76Hk

2020-11-21 13:15:14#sport#Meet the lockdown super-athletes ripping up the record books#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/meet-lockdown-super-athletes-ripping-131514431.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/vQIWAGtLI094bipmep7AbQ--~B/aD0xMTQ2O3c9MTgzMTthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/79fbcecd7ae02783c860d24ca9547765#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#At the Guinness World Records London headquarters this has been
column2: well
column3: a record year.  On their website
column4: there is a note explaining that the standard 12-week period required to verify records has been extended by at least a fortnight.  For the simple reason that they have been inundated with claims.  Lockdown
column5: it seems
column6: turned us into a nation of record breakers.  And according to Rory Coleman
column7: who
column8: by adding another 17
column9: took the opportunity to extend his world record of marathons this year to 1
column11: there is one person to thank for the upsurge.  “Captain Tom
column12: ” he says of the centenarian fundraiser.  “He showed us the way.  Loads of people thought
column13: wow if he’s doing it why aren’t I? We’re all driven to achieve.  And because covid has meant there have been no organised races
column14: where else do you get the satisfaction of achievement? By rewriting the record books. ” That was certainly the aim of Alan Colville.  A keen road racer
column15: he had anticipated spending his summer competing in cycling events.  Instead
column16: like the rest of us
column17: he was confined to home.  “Lockdown brought a context where racing bikes wasn’t an option.  In those times you look for different stuff to test yourself
column18: ” he explains.  “Suddenly I had more time
column19: I wasn’t travelling for work
column20: I didn’t feel as stressed.  So it freed my mind to take on a challenge. ” And the one he took on was sizeable.  An accomplished hill climber
column21: who
column22: as lockdown was imposed
column23: had already completed what is known as The Everest (cycling up the equivalent height of the world’s highest mountain)
column24: he started to think about how high he could climb.  “In May I did a double Everest on my indoor bike
column25: ” he says.  “And I discovered I was built for it.  I only weigh 57kg
column27: I really enjoyed it.  Then I got my head around the idea that it might be possible to break the world record for climbing in 48 hours. ” Around the same time
column29: a veteran of many an ultra-marathon
column30: wondered what she might do after her sport was curtailed.  “As lockdown happened
column31: I saw the races I’d normally train for disappearing.  I thought it was right to use the time to plan an adventure instead.  Breaking the LEJOG [Land’s End to John O’Groats] record popped into my head.  And it stuck there. ” There is a significant gap
column33: between thinking you might go for a record and actually doing it.  As Colville discovered.  “Part of the challenge is the organisation.  Guinness issues a set of guidelines specific to the event you are going for.  They set out the evidence you need to acquire to verify that you have achieved what you claim to have done. ” Then there is the planning for the event: the back-up
column35: the kit.  “I talked to a lot of people who’d done LEJOG who told me there was no way I could do this year
column36: ” says Molinaro.  “It takes so much organisation
column37: they reckoned the earliest I could do it was the summer of 2021.  I thought: nah I’m really fit
column38: I’m going for this.  It took three months to plan.  But then I didn’t have anything else to do. ” The first thing Colville required was a suitable place to attempt his record.  After weeks of research
column39: he found a hill in Wales
column44: ” he says.  “And it had a good mobile signal.  It ticked all those boxes. ” So in early September
column47: he set off.  “The idea was to cycle for 46 of the 48 hours.  Every minute you stopped
column49: you were down 12 metres.  We had all sorts of plans
column52: pacing.  I used to eat while sitting on the toilet to save time. ” Around the same time
column53: Molinaro had begun in Land’s End.  To break the record for the 874 miles to the north of Scotland
column54: she would need to cover at least 72 miles a day for 12 straight days.  It was an astonishingly demanding schedule. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/meet-lockdown-super-athletes-ripping-131514431.html#29TRsyVLm

column1: 2020-11-20 20:50:32#sport#How Dolly Parton Saved Christmas (on the Square)-and the Entire Human Race#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/dolly-parton-saved-christmas-square-205032073.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/WcLrEDAu5RK4Mm8RMNdnKg--~B/aD02NTg7dz0xMTcwO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/https://media.zenfs.com/en-US/thedailybeast.com/39a988ac7da973e1d7c250519146c4d7#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#This is a preview of our pop culture newsletter The Daily Beast’s Obsessed
column2: written by senior entertainment reporter Kevin Fallon.  To receive the full newsletter in your inbox each week
column3: sign up for it here. * * *We Literally Wouldn’t Survive Without Dolly Parton* * *I had been all excited to watch Dolly Parton’s Christmas musical on Netflix and write some hyperbolic and
column4: let’s face it
column5: obvious headline about how “Dolly Parton Saved Christmas!” only to realize that 1) I had apparently already written that headline before
column6: and 2) I was selling the Backwoods Barbie far short.  It turns out our Smoky Mountain queen isn’t just saving Christmas
column7: she’s saving the whole danged human race. Dolly Parton’s Christmas on the Square hits Netflix Sunday
column8: less than a week after it was revealed the music legend helped to fund the research that went toward the Moderna vaccine for COVID-19.  I don’t know how it wasn’t on our 2020 Bingo card that it would be Ms.  Parton who swoops in to rescue us from a pandemic.  Of course it would be her.  The record speaks for itself:And if that weren’t enough
column9: now she’s gifting us a Christmas movie
column10: too.  Having seen it
column11: I can say it’s about 94. 5 percent effective in delivering a pleasant time. Dolly Parton’s Christmas on the Square may rank among the most earnest things I have ever seen.  It announces itself as such immediately
column12: with Dolly Parton crooning on a studio set as a glowing
column13: sparkling angel posing as a hobo—what if God was one of us
column14: truly—before townspeople start pirouetting down the sidewalk and rhyming “Christmas on the square” with “thermal underwear” in the big opening number. It’s either get on board or get run over by the train with the unapologetic sincerity and schmaltz.  Could something as cheesy as this thrive at any other time? Regardless
column15: it’s a welcome treat to shed the snakeskin of cynicism and despair and just give in to the wholesome world of Dolly Parton at Christmas. In yet another saintly act
column16: Parton has given us a musical in which regal queen Christine Baranski is the lead.  She plays Regina Fuller
column17: a Scrooge in heels who returns to her hometown just before Christmas to tell everyone that she’s selling the land in order to build a giant mall
column18: and they all gotta go.  Only now do I realize that I hadn’t truly lived before seeing Christine Baranski speak-sing an eviction notice in time to a dramatic musical interlude. This Christmas Square has everything: Gays voguing in a hair salon
column19: a pastor and his wife toasting eggnog to fertility treatments
column20: tap dancing in the bank line
column21: a homeless Dolly Parton. The cast is a Who’s Who of Gay Twitter faves.  There’s Baranski
column22: of course
column23: but also Mother of Black Hollywood Jenifer Lewis
column24: The Other Two’s Hot Idiot (Josh Segarra)
column25: the best So You Think You Can Dance contestant ever (Jeanine Mason)
column26: and sexy dad icon Treat Williams.  It is directed by none other than Miss Debbie Allen. There are A Christmas Carol and It’s a Wonderful Life vibes all over the place.  Regina used to live in the town and her father was everyone’s favorite.  After he died
column27: her heart iced over—hence the holiday evictions—and it’s Angel Dolly’s mission to thaw it. In these scenes
column28: Parton floats over Regina on a billowy cloud
column29: which only raises the issue of how we figure out a way to provide exclusive cumulonimbus transport for Dolly Parton going forward.  It’s what she deserves. There’s a heartrending plot in which Regina meets a young girl wise beyond her years
column30: whose story about losing her mother forces Regina to consider the impact of her actions—especially when tragedy later befalls her
column31: too.  And just when you think you have things figured out
column32: there’s a shockingly intense secret pregnancy and adoption storyline.  Dolly Parton always keeping us on our toes!There are some beautiful Christian ballads—Parton
column34: gets the best ones—and some real corny clunkers.  Sometimes it’s hard to shake the feeling that you’re watching the best community theater production to ever hit Netflix.  It’s an aesthetic that’s best to embrace
column35: as approaching this movie with even an ounce of jadedness would render it unwatchable. There is a lot of talk about the power of prayer and faith.  There are SEVERAL dance production numbers that are set inside of a church.  It’s perhaps the one film that fits in the Venn diagram sweet spot of the Christian agenda and the gay agenda.  Once again
column36: the power of Dolly. No one would argue that what’s going on here is brilliant
column37: or even the best of the myriad new Christmas movies piling up on networks and streaming service like an insurmountable snowdrift. But there’s something refreshing about how heartfelt it is.  If you thought there was going to be a Christmas musical about a Dolly Parton angel changing Christine Baranski’s life that also has a dad singing prayers that his little girl doesn’t die after a car accident and that wouldn’t shatter my brittle-ass gingerbread cookie of a heart until I’m yelping back tears
column38: well… I just don’t know what to tell you. Read more at The Daily Beast. Get our top stories in your inbox every day.  Sign up now!Daily Beast Membership: Beast Inside goes deeper on the stories that matter to you.  Learn more. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/dolly-parton-saved-christmas-square-205032073.html#1FuuppqkB

column1: 2020-11-17 08:00:29#sport#Underwater museum: how 'Paolo the fisherman' made the Med's strangest sight#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/underwater-museum-paolo-fisherman-made-080029029.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/i9rMIYEfl0FkHGbmNgV8LQ--~B/aD0zMDA7dz01MDA7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_guardian_765/a272abc9327b749de5d6a4bc0a594e16#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#In a bid to stop illegal trawling
column2: an Italian fisherman persuaded sculptors to create huge marble artworks – then dropped them in the MediterraneanAs a child
column3: Paolo Fanciulli was fascinated by underwater shipwrecks
column4: particularly the fish and algae that lived in them.  He became a fisherman in the Tuscan village of Talamone at 13 and still plies the waters at the age of 60 in his small boat
column5: the Sirena.  But in the past decade
column6: his job has become harder
column7: as trawling near the coast has been destroying the marine ecosystem. The impact is devastating.  “The nets are weighed down with heavy chains to be dragged on the sea bottom
column8: so they uproot all the posidonia
column9: the seagrass that is key to the Mediterranean ecosystem because sea bream
column10: lobsters and red gurnards lay their eggs there
column11: ” he says. “They don’t care.  Nobody is watching
column12: ” he adds.  “It’s like if a hunter burned a whole forest to catch a hare. ”While Italian law bans trawling within three nautical miles of the coast
column13: it’s so profitable that it’s not uncommon for boats to carry on illegally at night.  Some employ lookouts to warn against the coast guard
column14: or use devices to shield their GPS signal. Fanciulli noticed the effects of trawling as early as the 1980s: the damaged ecosystem was affecting his catch and having an impact on his livelihood.  So
column15: along with some other local fishermen and activists from Greenpeace
column16: he blocked a commercial port in Tuscany in protest. It was the beginning of a struggle that has made him something of a local celebrity.  Fanciulli has destroyed trawling nets with barbed wire.  He once stopped a trawler by pretending to be the police.  His activism has seen him interviewed on German and Chinese TV
column17: and people in Talamone regularly stop “Paolo il Pescatore” – Paolo the Fisherman – to inquire about his newborn son. It also earned him enemies
column18: he says: threats from local mafia soon made it impossible for him to sell his fish at the market. He turned instead to what he describes as “pascaturismo”
column19: or fishing tourism: he takes visitors out on his boat
column20: giving them a chance to catch fish and learn about the ecological threat of trawling.  He also runs a small restaurant at weekends
column21: and sells his catch to the Gruppi di Acquisto Solidale
column22: a collective of Italian families buying ethical products. It wasn’t enough to stop illegal fishing
column24: a desperate Tuscan government dropped concrete blocks into the sea in an effort to disrupt the trawlers.  Fanciulli says they didn’t work
column26: as they were too far apart and the nets simply dragged between them. He got permission from Arpa
column28: to drop an additional 80 blocks at his own expense.  Still
column31: and his thoughts turned to the shipwrecks he’d loved as a boy.  “I didn’t just want concrete
column32: ” he says.  “I was fascinated with beautiful antiquities underwater. ”He began to wonder: what if
column33: instead of dropping concrete blocks into the water
column34: he dropped art?He asked a quarry in nearby Carrara if they could donate two marble blocks that he could use to make sculptures.  “They donated 100 instead. ”Via word of mouth
column35: contributions from tourists and online crowdfunding
column36: Fanciulli persuaded artists including Giorgio Butini
column38: Beverly Pepper and Emily Young to carve sculptures from the marble.  Then he took them out to sea and lowered them in. The underwater sculptures create both a physical barrier for nets and a unique underwater museum.  The sculptures are placed in a circle
column40: with an obelix at the centre carved by the Italian artist Massimo Catalani.  Emily Young provided four sculptures
column42: she calls “guardians”; nearby lies a mermaid by the young artist Aurora Vantaggiato.  Lippi has contributed 17 sculptures representing Siena’s contrade
column43: or medieval districts. The “museum” is open to anyone who can arrange a visit – either through guided scuba tours or by arranging their own dive. It’s located along the Argentario section of the Tuscan coast
column44: which has been plagued by trawling
column45: and this year boats have been caught carrying illegal nets and fishing in protected waters. Biologist Roberto Danovaro
column46: who heads the Anton Dohrn research institute in Naples
column47: likened trawling to “fishing with bombs”.  “You catch the fish
column49: ” he says.  “With no possibility of growing back because trawling is so intense. ”But the museum appears to be having some effect.  Whereas 10 years ago the Posidonia was disappearing
column53: says it is now growing back. The statues also deserve credit for helping to preserve the fishing industry
column54: she says: they “protect the fish resources because the nursery areas of various commercial fish species are located below the coast”. Marine life of all kinds appears to be returning.  Algae covers the statues
column55: and lobsters have taken up residence nearby.  Talamone is a turtle recovery centre – part of the Tartalife project – and more turtles have been seen
column56: as have dolphins.  “In the past it was unusual to see dolphins near the coast
column58: but as industrial fishing destroyed the seabed
column59: they moved close to the statues because
column61: there is food. ”The museum is Fanciulli’s version of the shipwrecks he loved as a boy
column62: and he hopes to build on its success.  “We put in the first statues in 2007 but our goal is to reach 100
column64: sensing an opportunity.  “We’d like someone to help our battle in defence of the sea.  Do you know if any soccer player or influencer is available?”#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/underwater-museum-paolo-fisherman-made-080029029.html#nmJGF1kA2

column2: I'm Leung Siu-wah.  People call me 'buffalo mother. ' Twelve years ago
column3: because this buffalo broke his leg and took shelter at my home
column4: I started to know more about buffalos. "" 'Buffalo Jean' cares for wounded water buffalos ""And I really love taking care of them and they really love being taken care by me too.  There are interactions
column5: and through these interactions
column6: we fell in love with each other.  We have loved each other for 12 years. "" There are roughly 100 wild buffalos on Lantau Island Jean uses her own savings and donations from residents to buy first aid and food ""So my everyday schedule is
column7: if the buffalos are not injured
column8: I play with them.  If they are injured
column9: I visit them every day at the same time.  They know I will be there
column10: they will wait for me.  After I handle their wounds
column11: I give them some food to eat. """#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/buffalo-mother-hong-kong-water-131553902.html#WUirRSwZr

column28: props and flankers who might otherwise miss out on college to play rugby while studying for four-year degrees. That pipeline

column67: ” Young says.  “And so the protests inspired MICR to launch our first ever diversity

2020-11-12 15:25:05#health#Baby gorilla engages in surprisingly human-like nose picking behavior#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/baby-gorilla-engages-surprisingly-human-152505557.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/dw5Ov0lf6._e7vXeEmtnrQ--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMTI1/https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-11/12/5fad55610da63801fae42100/5fad55610da63801fae42101_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Gorillas capture our fascination and our hearts as we watch them and we are reminded in many ways of ourselves.  Capable of very human behaviours and even similar facial expressions
column2: it is not difficult to believe that we are so closely related.  This gorilla baby is enjoying some affectionate time with his mother
column3: having just had his morning milk.  But what he does after he is finished is a behaviour that we have all seen young human children do very frequently.  He sticks a finger up his nose
column4: looks at what he has pulled out and promptly pops his finger into his mouth.  He repeats this several times in a way that looks as if he has been exposed to human children and he has learned this from them.  The truth is that this baby has almost definitely not see this action performed by people and that he has simply learned it on his own for whatever reason.  This might suggest that some of the same instinctive behaviour is influencing the gorillas and ourselves in a similar way.  These are western lowland gorillas
column5: the smaller of the subspecies
column6: yet the males can reach a weight of 270kg (600lbs).  They have incredible strength and are reported to be 7-8 times as powerful as an Olympic weightlifter
column7: although this is not easily verified.  standing erect
column8: can reach a height of almost 2m (6ft).  They possess formidable teeth and jaw strength
column9: capable of a biting force that is greater than a large dog.  Despite such immense power
column10: gorillas are generally calm and non-aggressive unless disturbed or threatened.  Even the adult males
column11: known as silverbacks
column12: are not likely to attack humans unless provoked.  The western lowland gorilla is a critically endangered species.  These gorillas live at the Toronto Zoo
column13: one of the world's highest rated zoos
column14: and recipient of numerous top awards related to conditions and health programs for the animals.  They are world leaders in conservation efforts and education.  When considering which facilities to support or avoid
column15: a little research goes a long way.  Supporting the organizations that are active in animal welfare around the world is crucial if we want to see animals like these survive. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/baby-gorilla-engages-surprisingly-human-152505557.html#3tSVQdJBO

column2: New Mexico#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/timelapse-captures-sunlit-clouds-moving-183021443.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-10/22/5f91cfde5068c30ea582aab4/5f91cfe208df0000016d5795_1620x1080_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#A New Mexico photographer captured timelapse footage of what looked like a rushing river of clouds from a mountain overlooking Albuquerque on Saturday
column3: October 17. Footage captured by Ian Beckley shows the clouds moving over Albuquerque from his perch on Sandia Crest mountain. Beckley told Storyful he decided to record a cloud video after he saw a cold front in the forecast that he thought would bring the right kind of cloudy conditions.  After six days of waking up at 2 am to drive to the top of Sandia Crest
column4: which is approximately 10
column5: 000 feet tall
column6: Beckley said the clouds dropped low enough for him to shoot the stunning sunrise video. “The city is at 6
column7: 000 feet and has mainly sunny days.  Getting any type of cloud inversion is very rare
column8: ” Beckley said. The National Weather Service predicted that a cold front would affect the region on the same date.  Credit: Ian Beckley via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/timelapse-captures-sunlit-clouds-moving-183021443.html#y2lMMZ9OI

column5: who was undergoing cancer treatment
column6: and harbored fears of Millie being upset by her absence.  “It was very hard to be away from her
column7: and I was a little concerned she would be upset with me for leaving for so long
column8: ” she told Storyful.  Thankfully
column9: those fears were unfounded and Millie gave her owner an enthusiastic welcome when she walked through her front door

column11: it was a lovely welcome home
column12: ” she added.  Credit: Johanna Wilson via Storyful#https://news.yahoo.com/pet-owner-returns-home-overjoyed-165715085.html#ysnf169ac

column1: 2020-10-22 19:26:53#health#Chimps and humans share same interest in later life: a bit of peace and quiet#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/chimps-humans-share-same-interest-192653859.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/_xBZ.jlTFVelC5A1XKuVFg--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMjUy/https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/qv_Brws0j.8fKOumtgEv2Q--~B/aD0xNTY2O3c9MjUwMjthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/50502496a33c74d427a7a652b0a95461#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"Chimpanzees narrow their social circle and increasingly seek peace and quiet in the same way as humans as they age
column2: a major study has found.  A study into wild chimpanzees
column3: based on 78
column4: 000 hours of observation
column5: found that the apes focused on fewer
column6: but more meaningful friendships in their later years.  Researchers claim it is the first evidence that a species other than humans alter how they socialise depending on their age.  Scientists from the Harvard department of human evolutionary biology looked at the social interactions of 21 chimps between the ages of 15 and 58 in a study spanning 1995 to 2016.  Their work was based at Kibale National Park in Uganda and focused specifically on male chimps
column7: which build stronger social bonds and are more socially active than females.  It was found that older chimps preferred spending more time with - and grooming - chimps they had developed mutual friendships with over the years.  Younger chimps
column8: however
column9: had more one-sided relationships where grooming wasn't always returned.  Older males were also more likely to spend more time alone but interacted with more important social partners like their ageing mutual friends
column10: the study
column11: published in the journal Science
column12: found.  Much like humans in their later years
column13: the older chimps sought out peace and quiet more regularly and tended to make their social interactions more positive than negative.  Alexandra Rosati
column14: an assistant professor of psychology and anthropology at the University of Michigan and one of the paper's lead authors
column15: said: ""The really cool thing is that we found that chimpanzees are showing these patterns that mirror those of humans. "" She added: ""There's really a pressing need to understand the biology of ageing.  ""More humans are living longer than in the past
column16: which can change the dynamics of ageing. "" Richard Wrangham
column17: professor of biological anthropology and founder and co-director of the Kibale Chimpanzee Project
column18: said: ""Even though chimps are very smart
column19: they do not understand they're going to die.  ""Much more likely something else is going on in chimps to explain why their relationships become more positive as they get older.  And then the question is what applies to chimps the same as what applies to humans. """#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/chimps-humans-share-same-interest-192653859.html#Hc66H8cFa
