2020-11-07 09:10:01#health#Life on the ocean wave: How joy and freedom can be found in surfing#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/life-ocean-wave-joy-freedom-091001339.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/wfprbz8UTqfNRD4kTdfqiw--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMjUw/https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/MeQXKSf7pYO3jZqDtA.IWQ--~B/aD0xNzk5O3c9Mjg3OTthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_818/8f31a78f9bc8fb0424ece2155ab7af4c#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Surfing has been part of Hawaiian culture since the fourth century
column2: when Polynesians arrived by canoe
column3: settled the islands and brought wave riding with them.  From its earliest mass swelling in the fertile heart of Polynesia
column4: the culture of surfing grew as a playful device for altering
column5: informing
column6: and reinforcing cultural values.  Early surfing cultures adopted wave riding for its ability to create camaraderie and provide physical challenge
column7: cultural cohesion
column8: and experiential spirituality.  The origins of surfing in Polynesia made it clear that this was a cultural practice of deep and meaningful play for everyone: mothers
column9: grandfathers
column10: warriors
column11: princesses
column12: children.  Play and travel were
column13: and still are
column14: entwined with the definitions of what it means to be a surfer.  As our ancient ancestors did
column15: we modern wave riders devote our lives to the pursuit of the vibrant edge that surfing offers – a deeply nourishing
column16: and highly addictive
column17: perpetual passion for one-more-wave that begs us on to both the most crowded and most remote swathes of sand by the planet’s oceans.  The sport and art of surfing was of such value to early Hawaiians that it was forbidden to work or wage war during prime surf season – everyone took a full three months off over winter for the Makahiki Festival
column18: a period of spiritual cleansing and sport.  The ancients knew what we have forgotten: play is part of what makes us human.  Working too hard or too often doesn’t necessarily lead to increased productivity or happiness
column19: or to a sense of community.  Neoteny – the retention of playful
column20: childlike characteristics – is an essential part of human evolution because it opens up doors to creativity
column21: spontaneity and visions of new ways of being in the world.  Most human cultures have tended to have more leisure time than work time.  In Hawaii
column22: a culture rich in aquatic lore and myth abounded before the threats of colonisation.  Surfing was part of a sensuous way of life that also included hula dancing
column24: and outlets for play entwined with spirituality.  But when European notions of religiosity
column25: gender and the Protestant work ethic came to govern Polynesia and beyond
column26: the wild freedom of wave riding was nearly lost
column27: and later assumed as an endeavour only for men.  Historians of Ancient Polynesia acknowledge that it was women
column29: who seemed to stand in the highest regard for their skill and poise as surfers.  Woven deep into the chants and lore of surfing culture are the stories of revered women – such as Pele
column31: and Princess Kelea – who rode the waves with the utmost grace and athleticism.  Right now
column32: women are reclaiming our natural place in the global sport
column33: art and culture of surfing.  While men’s performances and perspectives have tended to dominate in surfing
column34: the past three decades have seen women’s participation increase exponentially.  Women now make up between 20 and 30 per cent of surfers
column35: and that number continues to grow. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/life-ocean-wave-joy-freedom-091001339.html#j7tHPZfBG

column1: 2020-10-29 13:45:38#entertainment#10 Scene-Stealing Cats in Movies
column2: From ‘Breakfast at Tiffany’s’ to ‘Captain Marvel’ (Photos)#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/10-scene-stealing-cats-movies-001638962.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/4LDuCWZMSm3LPchAs0HV5A--~B/aD00MDA7dz02MTg7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://media.zenfs.com/en-US/thewrap.com/a14579d24ef204b390022828e246235d#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Goose
column3: “Captain Marvel” (2019)Okay
column4: Goose is technically not a cat.  Carol Danvers’ orange sidekick is actually a flerken (an alien with massive tentacles hidden inside her mouth)
column5: but Goose’s fluffy coat and knack for getting into trouble puts her firmly in the cat category. Binx
column6: “Hocus Pocus” (1993)Thackery Binx was just a normal teenage boy in 1693 before he was cursed to live forever in the body of a black cat.  But hey
column7: everyone goes through weird phases in their teens. Cat
column8: “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” (1961)Let’s make this clear: Holly Golightly does not own this cat.  He belongs to nobody and nobody belongs to him.  But that doesn’t stop him from playing a pivotal role in the movie
column9: including the tear-jerking final scene. Jonesy
column10: “Alien” (1979)This orange tabby was the unofficial mascot of the USCSS Nostromo and one of the few crew members to survive a Xenomorph attack.  He also remains the only character to successfully steal a scene from Sigourney Weaver. Mr.  Jinx
column11: “Meet the Parents” (2000)This movie should actually be called “Meet the Parents’ Cat
column12: ” because Mr.  Jinx is the real star.  The perpetually-frowning Himalayan cat is Jack Byrnes’ pride and joy
column13: and knows how to come when called
column14: wave and even use the toilet.  That’s called a ‘triple threat’ in showbiz. Tonto
column15: “Harry and Tonto” (1974)Art Carney’s portrayal of a feisty retiree on a cross-country road trip won him an Academy Award
column16: while his feline costar didn’t even get a nomination.  What gives?Church
column17: “Pet Sematary” (1989
column18: 2019)Ellie Creed’s playful kitty Winston Churchill was run over by a truck and came back from the dead as Church to terrorize his former owners.  That’s something to consider before burying your cat in a cursed cemetery. Ulysses
column19: “Inside Llewyn Davis” (2013)This honey-colored tabby joined Oscar Isaac’s grumpy folk musician as he wandered around New York City and Chicago in the Coen brothers’ film.  Though he takes up more screen time than many of the human actors
column20: the feline actor isn’t named in the credits — perhaps because the character was played by three separate (but equally adorable) animal performers. Mr.  Bigglesworth
column21: “Austin Powers” series When Dr.  Evil’s cat
column22: Mr.  Bigglesworth
column25: Dr.  Evil doesn’t sound too different from the average cat owner. Fat Louie
column26: “The Princess Diaries” (2001)Behind every great princess of Genovia is an equally great black-and-white kitty. Read original story 10 Scene-Stealing Cats in Movies
column27: From ‘Breakfast at Tiffany’s’ to ‘Captain Marvel’ (Photos) At TheWrap#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/10-scene-stealing-cats-movies-001638962.html#mrhkTcVFM

column1: 2020-10-30 22:00:06#health#This Superfood Might Someday Save Your Life
column2: Study Finds#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/superfood-might-someday-save-life-220006285.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/8exTgRnPhH4bhlJBnBKy5w--~B/aD04Nzk7dz0xMjAwO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/https://media.zenfs.com/en/galvanized/aa4863d9945792913b4a7d3761f87c45#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"Go ahead
column3: pull up to that big plate of salmon.  Grab a nice big handful of walnuts.  Both of these foods are rich in omega-3 fatty acids (aka ""essential fatty acids"")
column4: which are long chains of fats that are actually good for you and are known for supporting heart health.  In fact
column5: new findings suggest that eating more of them regularly may even help save your life if you were to ever suffer from a heart attack. A recent study published in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology took a look at heart attack patients who were admitted to the hospital and found that those who had higher blood levels of omega-3 fatty acids were less likely to die
column6: or even require re-hospitalization
column7: during the three years following their heart attack compared to other patients.  Specifically
column8: this research looked for two kinds omega-3s—eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and alpha-linolenic acid (ALA)—in the bloodwork of 944 heart attack patients with an average age of 61
column9: 209 of which were women.  (Related: 21 Best Healthy Cooking Hacks of All Time. )EPA has already been associated with a lower risk of heart attack
column10: and its best-known food source is fatty fish
column11: including salmon and mackerel.  ALA has also already been associated with a lower risk of death in the event of a heart attack
column12: and its best food sources include walnuts
column13: flaxseeds
column14: and canola oil.  After following the heart attack patients' progress for three years
column15: the researchers found that those with higher levels of EPA and ALA in their blood at the time they were admitted to the hospital for a heart attack were more likely to be alive at the end of the study.  Those with higher levels of EPA were also less likely to require readmission to the hospital during that timeframe.  From this
column16: the scientists concluded that a diet rich in omega-3s could serve as a smart heart attack prevention strategy.  So
column17: with that in mind
column18: here are 21+ healthy salmon recipes you can make tonight (and often!) in the name of good heart health. For more up-to-the-minute healthy eating news
column19: sign up for our newsletter. "#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/superfood-might-someday-save-life-220006285.html#k5wZM4ILV

column1: 2020-10-21 10:00:25#tech#Calves adorably startled when they tip over the camera#https://www.msn.com/en-us/travel/other/calves-adorably-startled-when-they-tip-over-the-camera/vi-BB1afATq?li=BBnbklE#https://www.msn.com/en-us/travel/other/calves-adorably-startled-when-they-tip-over-the-camera/vi-BB1afATq?li=BBnbklE#en#1.0#www.msn.com#Calves are incredibly curious animals that sniff and lick at almost anything new that they discover in their meadow.  More inquisitive and more intelligent than we give them credit for
column2: they are much like giant puppies in their personalities.  These calves live on a beautiful farm in Millbrook
column3: Ontario.  They wander freely in the meadow for most of the year
column4: exploring the woods and rolling hills
column5: and they drink fresh water from the ponds on the farm.  They are part of a large
column6: and very happy herd that enjoy the freedom here
column7: grazing contentedly throughout the day.  They are joined by Gus
column8: a huge
column9: but relaxed bull that watches over his herd protectively.  These calves have gathered around to check out a new visitor in their meadow.  They are very curious about the small camera that he has and they watch him carefully
column10: although they are reluctant to approach him close enough to sniff at the strange object that he is holding.  He puts the camera down in the grass and moves back a few steps.  Predictably
column11: the calves gather around and look even more closely.  They can't resist the urge to get a good look and even lick at the camera.  The result is some very adorable footage of their noses and eyes peering right into the lens.  But when one of them nudges the camera and it tips over in the grass
column12: they all jump in unison and get ready to run.  When nothing dangerous happens
column13: they slowly return to their investigation of the amusing object. #https://www.msn.com/en-us/travel/other/calves-adorably-startled-when-they-tip-over-the-camera/vi-BB1afATq?li=BBnbklE#n0JlQQkST

2020-10-20 15:27:26#entertainment#Fox That Was Trapped on Overturned Boat in River Thames Released Into Wild After Rescue#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/fox-trapped-overturned-boat-river-152726689.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-10/20/5f8f023ee75f6910927b52dc/5f8f023ee75f6910927b52dd_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#A fox that had been trapped on an overturned boat on the River Thames was released back into the wild after it was rescued by the London Fire Brigade and the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals on October 17
column2: the RSPCA said. Members of the public had seen the fox trapped in Saint Saviour’s Dock
column3: Southwark
column4: on a muddy bank.  The fox had been cornered by the river and the incoming tide
column5: RSPCA inspector Rebecca Phillips said in a press release by the animal welfare group. As the water rose
column6: the animal sought safety on the hull of the small rowboat. “He climbed onto the hull of the boat to escape the water.  Firefighters managed to hook the rope for the boat
column7: and carefully pulled it over to a scaffolding platform
column8: crossing the river underneath a bridge so we could try to catch him
column9: ” Phillips said. According to the same press release
column10: as rescuers prepared their equipment and assessed the best way to catch the fox
column11: the frightened critter slipped off the boat and into the water. Phillips said that she looked “frantically” for a minute and heard scratching underneath her feet
column12: before spotting the fox
column13: who had jumped onto a scaffolding pole below. “I managed to loop my grasper around his body to secure him and get a hand onto his rear end to pull him up onto the platform
column14: ” she said.  “We’d attracted quite a crowd
column15: so it’s great that they were able to see him being saved and that we got a lovely
column16: happy ending. ”The fox was fed and dried off
column17: before he was brought to a safe place and released back into the wild.  Credit: RSPCA via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/fox-trapped-overturned-boat-river-152726689.html#LZs5LgCe7

PHIL YOUR STORY: Hopelessly in need of Dr.  Phil's Help? Austin Farm Sanctuary is a non-profit animal rescue and home to over 65 animals.  They are featured in Dr.  Phil and Richard Linklater’s new 10-episode documentary series
column4: That Animal Rescue Show

column7: and learn more about Austin Farm Sanctuary.  WATCH: How Safe In Austin Rescue Animals Help Abused And Special Needs Children Heal That Animal Rescue Show premieres on CBS All Access on October 29.  On Wednesday’s episode of Dr.  Phil

column1: 2020-11-11 21:08:23#entertainment#Teacher on TikTok shares 'genius' trick to make sure her students pay attention#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/teacher-tiktok-shares-genius-trick-210823121.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-11/11/5fac5308e75f6974498588d0/5fac530d42977000016b4538_1920x1080_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#TikTok user The Creator Educator explained a teaching hack that involves hiding an “extra
column2: ” sillier task in the instructions of a quiz.  Her instruction was to meow like a cat — out loud — during the assignment.  students received bonus points if they meowed on their test — but apparently
column3: more than 90 percent of them failed to do so.  As several kids meowed
column4: some students seemed baffled by the situation.  “Why was everyone saying ‘meow?'”.  As one of her students explained
column5: it was “a test to see who was listening”.  The method earned praise from parents and teachers on TikTok
column6: with several users commenting that it was a “great idea”.  “My high schoolers would start meowing just because others were
column7: ” one user wrote.  Others were more critical
column8: saying many students might feel too nervous to make a strange noise out loud during a test.  “Sounds good except my son has anxiety that won’t allow him to do that
column9: ” one user wrote#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/teacher-tiktok-shares-genius-trick-210823121.html#CnoS9Rh8O

column2: who she thought was in Australia
column3: that friend suddenly popped up in the backseat
column4: leading to shrieks of joyous laughter. Katie was recording video for her friend Helen
column5: and can be heard saying
column6: “Love you
column7: Helen!” Helen then pulls the covers off herself and pops her head out of the backseat
column8: saying
column9: “Love you too!” to Katie and their other friend Myriam. Helen had surprised Myriam the day before and had enlisted her help to surprise her friend
column10: which took place while Katie was waiting to pick up her boyfriend in County Wicklow. Describing Katie’s reaction to seeing her after three years apart
column11: Helen said it was “the best reaction ever caught on video. ” Credit: Helen Flynn via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/irishwoman-pops-cars-backseat-surprise-174827615.html#e8QyBdZT7

column1: 2020-11-05 22:01:52#entertainment#50 Adorable Puppy Pictures That Will Put a Smile on Your Face#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/50-adorable-puppy-pictures-put-220152454.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/vEGPEvJQN4yduwV57MfSag--~B/aD04MDE7dz0xMjAwO2FwcGlkPXl0YWNoeW9u/https://media.zenfs.com/en-US/best_life_342/02be3a70ad7144b858d54f199dfa1b7f#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"There's nothing like a cute puppy to turn a rainy day around.  Don't have access to your own playful pooch? Simply perusing snaps of some photogenic four-legged friends can make you feel better.  Not only that
column2: but a 2012 study published in PLOS One proved that looking at images of cute animals can actually make you more productive.  When you look at it that way
column3: you can't afford not to! So if you're in the mood for a burst of serotonin—or just flat out need it to make it through the rest of your workday—let us make that happen with these 50 precious puppy pictures.  And for more highly necessary animal content
column4: check out 28 Cow Photos That Are Too Adorable for Words.  1 This Frenchie sweet peaThis is truly the face of unconditional love. For some precious pups who are beautiful in their own way
column5: check out 13 ""Ugly"" Dogs Who Are Really Just Adorably Unique.  2 This little Chihuahua who's all dressed up for the rainHe's fancy and he knows it.  3 This little Husky who knows how to high-fivePuppies love learning new tricks!For more dogs who just want to be friends with everyone they meet
column6: check out 25 Adorable Photos of Puppies Playing With Other Animals.  4 This English Cocker Spaniel who just wants some attentionHe can fit his whole head into his food bowl! The cuteness is practically unbearable.  5 This happy Husky with his proud papaHe's teaching him to be big and strong. For the most loyal species in nature
column7: check out 25 Adorable Animals That Mate for Life.  6 This Goldie protecting his little sisterWho says cats and dogs can't be friends? Puppies will play with anyone.  7 This little beagle learning how to howlThis one's got a feisty spirit
column8: and we love it. As proof that pups are the best babysitters ever
column9: here are 27 Precious Photos of Dogs and Babies That Will Melt Your Heart.  8 The floppy-eared CorgiThis is just one of the many reasons Corgis make the best pets.  9 This happy German shepherd playing fetchShe's got her eye on the prize!For more heart-melting animals sent right to you inbox
column10: sign up for our daily newsletter.  10 This charming little fella on his first trip to the vetHe's learning the proper pup-cedure in case of an emergency.  11 This little angelThis is definitely what heaven looks like.  12 This Goldie who just wants to love youHe'd like some kibble but will also accept just a head scratch.  13 This little EinsteinHe'd make an excellent pawfessor.  14 This little Frenchie that loves to splootWatching a puppy learn how to walk is one of the great joys of life.  15 This little one just enjoying the sunshinePuppies know that it's all about the little things
column11: which is what makes them so inspiring.  16 This smushy flooferSleepy animals are the best kinds of animals.  17 This dachshund learning how to flyDumbo
column12: is that you? 18 This gentle Aussie sitting in a treeHe is one with nature and nature is one with him.  19 This baby girl and her Labrador bestieIt really doesn't get any better than tiny dogs and their tiny human companions.  20 This little Samoyed who just doesn't want to walk anymoreHe just wants to be held.  21 This terrier mix who just wants to snuggleShe's living proof that mixed breed dogs are absolutely gorgeous.  22 This Chocolate Lab with a bow around her neckAs if we needed a reminder that her existence is a gift to humankind.  23 This very small boyGuaranteed to steal your girl.  24 This proud British BulldogHe may be small in size
column13: but in his imagination
column14: he's large and in charge.  25 This starry-eyed Siberian HuskyHe's seeing rainbows wherever he goes.  26 This snoozing Jack Russell TerrierShe actually looks like a cartoon.  27 This Corgi strutting his stuffHe's doing his little turn on the catwalk.  28 This innocent cutie pieThose eyes can never tell a lie.  29 This coy Cavalier King Charles SpanielShe wants something and
column15: realistically
column16: she's probably going to get it.  30 This Goldie at golden hourWhere can we get tickets for this inspirational movie? 31 This Goldie who just wants to playThere's nothing more adorable than when they bring you your toys.  32 This naughty boyIt's OK
column17: we all have our vices
column18: and you can't stay mad at a face like that for long.  33 This shelter pup looking up hopefullyCould you give him a forever home? 34 This beach boyHe loves fun in the sun with his fluffy bum.  35 This silly girlShe is patiently waiting for belly rubs.  36 This beautiful baby King Charles CavalierThis puppy is prettier than most people we know.  37 This panicked pupA canine representation of us when we jump to conclusions.  38 This adventure buddyHe is ready to go for a ride or a run anytime.  39 This majestic pup mid-strideHe loves fall as much as the rest of us.  40 This zen pupShe is unwinding after a ruff day.  41 This Welsh Corgi who loves a pile of crunchy leaves. Jumping into one is one of the best parts of fall
column19: and he knows it.  42 This pit bull puppy showing you her biiiiig stretchIt's the only way to start the day! 43 This Maltese puppy giving you his saddest eyesJust give him that taco you're eating.  We promise
column20: you'll feel better.  44 This Pomeranian who needs her beauty restShe's hit the snooze three times
column21: and she's not sorry.  45 This pup on a mission for sticksThis gal coming through with the find of the century—the ultimate chew toy.  46 These German shepherds holding pawsLife is hard—sometimes you need a paw to hold.  47 This puppy who really did eat your homeworkIf your teacher doesn't believe you
column22: show them this picture.  48 This wrinkled boyHis eyes are in there somewhere.  49 This pug puppy who's in her favorite spotShe's training to be a lap dog.  50 This goofy girl who just wants to see you smileHow'd she do?Additional reporting by Allie Hogan. column2: 200 Miles to Reunite With Missing Dog in Tennessee Shelter#https://news.yahoo.com/man-drives-1-200-miles-192513212.html#https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/RSY3.LA6BYSu8dZ79Gg11g--~B/aD03MjA7dz0xMjgwO3NtPTE7YXBwaWQ9eXRhY2h5b24-/https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-10/25/5f95d169b2ac5f0eadcaab0a/5f95d16ecefccd0001f2506a_1280x720_FES_v1.jpg#en#1.0#news.yahoo.com#A dog owner drove 1
column3: 200 miles to a Tennessee animal shelter to reunite with his missing pet on October 18
column4: the Washington County Animal Shelter said.  “Just over 6 months ago
column5: Blue went missing
column6: ” the animal shelter wrote on Facebook.  “His owner Pat searched and searched but couldn’t find him.  And then he had to move to Texas for his work.  He thought he’d never see Blue again. ” The shelter said Pat’s friend spotted a video showing his beloved pet playing ball at their facility
column7: prompting Pat to contact them immediately to make arrangements.  Footage posted to Facebook shows the moment Pat was reunited with Blue after making the trip from Texas to Johnson City
column8: Tennessee
column9: where the shelter is located.  “We don’t many happy endings like this one
column10: ” the shelter wrote.  “There were some tears
column11: tons of doggie kisses and lots of smiles.  What a great story!” Credit: Washington County Animal Shelter via Storyful#https://news.yahoo.com/man-drives-1-200-miles-192513212.html#Bwpm9jbyQ

2020-10-28 23:58:39#tech#This gigantic Galapagos tortoise will leave you in awe#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/gigantic-galapagos-tortoise-leave-awe-235839320.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/SMZ6Lo_615I6uvFQVNY4Ag--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMTI1/https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-10/29/5f9a06ff0da6381067424f60/5f9a06ff0da6381067424f61_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Abigail lives on the island of Santa Cruz
column2: in the Galapagos.  The island has lush green forested areas in the highlands
column3: dry areas on the coast that resemble an arid desert
column4: a thriving town
column5: and wildlife that is diverse and fascinating.  One of the most iconic animals in the world
column6: the giant Galapagos Tortoise makes its home here.  Loved and well protected by the residents
column7: these tortoises have seen a dramatic increase in numbers since their conservation efforts have been implemented.  The tortoises draw thousands of tourists each year
column8: which is important to people living in this remote world.  The tortoises also represent a very important part of the overall health of the fragile ecosystem.  Galapagos tortoises wander freely on Santa Cruz.  There are rehab and captive breeding centers
column9: as well as more protected areas
column10: but the tortoises are free to roam wherever they please
column11: often making long treks to find nesting areas or breeding opportunities.  Living as long as 200 years
column12: and possibly longer
column13: these tortoises will lay many eggs in their lifetime.  They will also grow to a staggering 225kg (500lbs) with a shell large enough to fill the passenger compartment of a small car.  It is always a treat for the residents
column14: or the tourists
column15: to find a tortoise on the move.  This giant male had taken a casual stroll down a bike path
column16: making his way from the highlands in the direction of the ocean far below.  Solon and his daughter were driving past in their electric car when they spotted the giant beast enjoying a rest and a meal at the side of the pedestrian/bike path.  They stopped so that Solon could capture the moment and also so that he could deliver a short nature lesson for Abigail and others who would see his video later.  Abigail seems interested enough
column17: but these are animals that she will see frequently as she grows up on this incredible island.  She will see sea lions
column18: pelicans
column19: crabs
column20: iguanas and stingrays here regularly as well.  These animals that the rest of us will likely only see on nature shows make their home all around her.  The people of the Galapagos Islands have a love and respect for the wildlife that is second to none.  They maintain their distance and respectfully avoid interfering with any of the animals.  They will gently guide or correct any of the tourists who are tempted to bend or break the rules with respect to distance or feeding of the wildlife
column21: knowing that nature does not need any help from mankind.  The people of the Galapagos Islands are leaders in environmental responsibility.  They have banned single use plastics.  They allow only taxis
column22: small motorcycles and electric cars on the island.  In this way
column23: pollution is kept to a minimum.  They also understand and protect the delicate balance that is important to the native species. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/gigantic-galapagos-tortoise-leave-awe-235839320.html#JT5izQd86

column1: 2020-10-21 11:00:37#entertainment#Grumpy looking robin has a great time bathing in backyard pond#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/grumpy-looking-robin-great-time-110037370.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/BgxxfjW2u62cEQjIh42gKA--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTEyODA7aD03MjA-/https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-10/21/5f90171af1b75b1406b11369/5f90171af1b75b1406b1136a_o_U_v2.jpg#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#"Robins are beautiful birds that inhabit most areas of North America and even Mexico.  Here we see one bathing in a backyard pond.  Although it looks very angry
column2: it's clear it is having a very good time! As it splashes and dips into the water
column3: the facial features and markings over the eyes make it appear to be holding a serious frown.  These birds are called ""American Robins"" because they are native to North America
column4: and because they have a red breast
column5: similar to the European robin.  But the European robin is flycatcher and is in a completely different family.  The American robin is actually a thrush
column6: and a songbird.  They are abundantly found in all types of habitat.  Robins are significant carriers and spreaders of the dangerous West Nile Virus.  Although we typically blame crows and jays for this spread
column7: because we see the die from it early and in larger numbers
column8: the robin is just as capable of contracting the virus and then living longer
column9: promoting a greater spread to humans through the mosquitos which are the intermediary hosts.  Robins have keen eyesight to help them find their prey; grubs
column10: insects and earthworms
column11: but they actually use their hearing to find food as well.  The robin listens carefully for the sound of an earthworm moving just beneath the surface of the ground.  It can detect the worm and pounce
column12: pulling it from its hole.  They use smell and even detect vibration to find their food.  It is believed that birds like the robin bathe in water or in dust to maintain the preferred amount of oil on their feathers and to discourage mites and other parasites. "#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/grumpy-looking-robin-great-time-110037370.html#nkJzZ6Jjy

column1: 2020-10-28 16:39:57#tech#Whales swap songs with other groups as they migrate
column2: scientists discover for first time#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/whales-swap-songs-other-groups-163957818.html#https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/TlikivTrroWfMuKd1e1eeA--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTIwMDA7aD0xMjUw/https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/qacv.o2k6hhKrNBNVZYnhQ--~B/aD0xNTYzO3c9MjUwMTthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/https://media.zenfs.com/en-GB/the_telegraph_258/c4d60f73d4603d12c655e01522a85b55#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Whales swap songs with other groups as they migrate
column3: scientists have discovered for the first time.  For years it was believed that the endangered Fin Whale sang just one song pattern
column4: which is unique to the males in his particular group.  But using underwater microphones researchers have discovered they can produce different melodies that spread to other parts of the ocean as groups travel.  A total of 116 whale encounters were analysed near Kauai
column5: which is part of the Hawaiian archipelago
column6: over the course of six years.  Recordings discovered that while male fin whales living in the Pacific Ocean only sing two notes at a very low pitch
column7: these are produced in different rhythms to create songs.  Five main patterns of songs were recorded in the area
column8: some of which were geographically unique
column9: but others were similar to those recorded in whale groups off the north-west coast of the US. #https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/whales-swap-songs-other-groups-163957818.html#LCqYrNIIn

column1: 2020-11-09 15:58:22#entertainment#Oregon Police Make Surprise Housecall to Celebrate Woman's 90th Birthday#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/oregon-police-surprise-housecall-celebrate-155822773.html#https://s.yimg.com/hd/cp-video-transcode/prod/2020-11/09/5fa967a50da6381067428285/5fa967a50da6381067428286_o_U_v2.png#en#1.0#www.yahoo.com#Police officers in Nyssa
column2: Oregon
column3: said they surprised a resident for her 90th birthday and left her with a “priceless” look of “surprise and appreciation. ”The Nyssa Police Department shared this footage on November 5 of officers greeting Shirley Lassiter and singing “Happy Birthday” to her.  In the video
column4: one officer shouts “Open the door! You have the right to have a happy 90th birthday
column5: Shirley Lassiter!”“One of the beautiful benefits of living and serving in our little town is that we can take a break from training to swing by and wish Mrs.  Shirley Lassiter a very Happy 90th Birthday with her friends and family.  She’s an amazing young lady
column6: ” the Nyssa Police Department said on Facebook.  Credit: Nyssa Police Department via Storyful#https://www.yahoo.com/lifestyle/oregon-police-surprise-housecall-celebrate-155822773.html#ONdm9twxO
